Headline: Barron's(3/12) The Striking Price: A Hedge Of One's Own
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Who dares wins.   That's the motto of Britain's Special Air Service commandos, and it is useful to remember for anyone contemplating the pricing discrepancies that have emerged among index and equity options following the stock market's recent gyrations.   While most investors have focused on benchmark indexes like the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the Chicago Board Options Exchange's Market Volatility Index, some of the most compelling action in the options market has occurred among stocks whose market-capitalizations exceed $20 billion. The implied volatility of these big-caps increased more than the benchmark indexes, but has attracted much less attention.   Long-term stock investors may want to take advantage of this by selling puts against their positions. Audacious traders may want to consider selling uncovered puts to bet that implied volatility will snap lower. Indeed, part of the reason for the big-cap "volatility rallies" is that money managers routinely buy defensive puts on liquid equity options during sharp market declines to create their own custom portfolio hedges rather than buying index options. The increase in put-buying drives implied volatility higher.   Stocks with unusually high three-month implied volatility, relative to their average levels, according to Goldman Sachs, include Allstate (ticker: ALL), Amgen (AMGN), Cisco Systems (CSCO), DuPont (DD), Intel (INTC), International Game Technology (IGT), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Microsoft (MSFT) and Pfizer (PFE). Financial stocks, including Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), JPMorgan (JPM), Capital One Financial (COF) and Wachovia (WB) also experienced sharp increases in implied volatility.   To be sure, selling puts isn't for everyone, especially when doubts remain about the stock market's trajectory over the next few months. If the trade doesn't work as planned, investors will find that even though they were paid upfront for selling the put, they may be the ones paying at the end if the market moves against them. Yet, some institutional traders believe selling puts against stock is similar to selling calls, with the primary difference that put selling has a more nuanced reputation, like short-selling stocks.   As a rule, investors should sell puts on stocks that they own, or would like to own. Most investors sell options that expire in three months because those are generally the most liquid, and the premiums are generally meaningful amounts. Options that expire in one month may have higher implied volatilities, but the risk of market moves is big.   Current market conditions introduce a few important variables for put sellers to consider. Sell puts on mega-cap stocks with high implied volatility if you think stocks were unfairly punished in the general market rout. Other reasons to sell those puts are if you believe the stock market sell-off is largely over, or if next wave of a sell-off will hit stocks with poor fundamentals.   While volatility trading is increasingly common at hedge funds as they try to beat the market, it is not as widespread among "real money," which is how people who deal with hedge funds refer to everyone else. To do it well, requires vigilance, because implied volatility tends to moves very quickly. But investors who dare may just win.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Fund Management Group Hanover Eyes UK's Plasmon -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Hanover Investors, the activist fund management group, has targeted a struggling U.K. company by taking a 24% stake and appointing two directors to the board at Plasmon (PLM.LN), the data storage maker, the Financial Times reported Saturday.   The move saw Plasmon's shares climb more than 36%, finishing up 7 1/2 pence at 28p.   According to the FT, Hanover's goal with active investments is to select poorly run companies and force management change.   Plasmon has struggled with weak sales of its ultra-density optical disks and drives while legacy products have continued to decline, leading to a drop in share price from 250p in 2004 to as low as 20p, the FT reported.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9375     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 07:03 ET (12:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Voice Diary Inc. Signs Contracts With DAR Farmers
Story: SUINING, Sichuan, China, March 10 /Xinhua-PRNewswire/ -- In order to effectively fulfill their contract with DongUi Cosmetics Co. ("DongUi"), a corporation organized and operating in the Republic of Korea (South Korea), Suining Yinfa DAR Industrial Co., Ltd. (DAR Industrial), a subsidiary of Voice Diary Inc., (OTC Bulletin Board: VCDY), is vigorously endeavoring to carry out its 2007 Dahurian Angelica Root (DAR) purchase plan. On March 8, 2007, DAR Industrial signed a contract with the Chuanshan District Hongjiang Village Residents' Committee in Suining, a legal entity collectively representing all of the farmers of the Hongjiang Village, for the purchase of 400 tons of newly produced DAR in 2007.  Thus far, DAR Industrial has procured through various contracts commitments to supply roughly 500 tons of DAR throughout 2007, all through GAP certified suppliers.  Out of the 500 tons of DAR that DAR Industrial has signed contracts for, approximately 60% is earmarked for export to South Korea.     DAR Industrial hopes to enter into DAR supply contracts with 22 villages before August of 2007.  If DAR Industrial can meet its goals in 2007 of signing supply contracts with 22 new villages in China, output capability could reach 3200 tons, then it would take up 56% of the total output of China. DAR Industrial hopes to utilize 40% of the DAR they purchase in DAR Industrial brand products such as DAR slices, DAR powder (used in nearly 600 different Chinese medicines), healthcare products, Bailing capsules, Yishen capsules and DAR perfume bags.  All of these products are currently being developed by DAR Industrial.        About the Company     Suining Yinfa DAR Industrial Co., Ltd. (DAR Industrial), a subsidiary of Voice Diary Inc. (VCDY), was incorporated on April 24, 2001.  It is one of China's leading industrialized agricultural corporations. DAR Industrial has focused on the production and further processing of Dahurian Angelica Root (DAR), an herb that is widely used in China, and considered to be an important ingredient Chinese traditional medicine. DAR Industrial's business plan includes distributing DAR and its related products to exploit a large market demand in the areas of treatment of pain, swelling and pustule.     Statements regarding financial matters in this press release other than historical facts are "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and as that term is defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. The company intends that such proclamations about future expectations, including future revenues and earnings and all other forward-looking statements be subject to the safe harbors created thereby. Voice Diary, Inc. depends on outside resources to maintain its continuation. Since these statements involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change at any time, the company's actual results may differ materially from expected results.          For more information, please contact:        Office of Voice Diary Inc.      343 Suining Zhong Road, Suining, Sichuan, P.R.China      Website: www.chinanaturalresource.com      Tel: 86-825-2391788      SOURCE  Suining Yinfa DAR Industrial Co., Ltd.       /CONTACT: Office of Voice Diary Inc., 86-825-2391788      /Web site: http://www.chinanaturalresource.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 02:31 ET (07:31 GMT)

Headline: Reliance Indus Board OKs Merger With Indian Petrochemicals
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--Indian refining and petrochemical major Reliance Industries Ltd. (500325.BY) said Saturday its board has approved a merger with associate company Indian Petrochemicals Corp. Ltd. (500105.BY) via a share swap.   Shareholders in IPCL, a firm in which RIL group companies held a 46.64% stake as of Dec. 31, will get one share in RIL for every five shares they hold in IPCL, said RIL in a joint statement with IPCL.   The board of IPCL also separately approved the merger, which is subject to regulatory and shareholder approvals, said the statement.     -By V. Phani Kumar; Dow Jones Newswires; 91 22 2288 4212; phani.kumar@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 03:41 ET (08:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) The Trader: A Bounceback Amid Weak Data, Weak Market
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   Happiness, as everyone knows, comes from within, not without -- so investors found some inner resolve and managed to scratch back a 1% gain last week, despite the generally uninspiring economic data.   Friday's figures were decent: The Labor Department said the U.S. economy added 97,000 jobs in February. The unemployment rate inched down to 4.5% from 4.6%, but the jobs rise was the smallest in two years.   Meanwhile, the February ISM non-manufacturing index fell to 54.3 from 59 the previous month, and January wholesale inventories, up 0.7%, are reinforcing investor fears that the U.S. economy is slowing. On balance, the past few weeks' numbers point to an economic softening -- not the recession that worried pundits fret about.   The market's backbone was reinforced by rising international bourses, buoying U.S. investors' spirits enough midweek to carry the rally through to Friday's mixed finish.   Small-caps outperformed large, especially on Friday, suggesting that investors' risk appetite hasn't disappeared. Still, market sentiment remains skittish, following late February's huge selloff.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed Friday at 12,276.32, up 1.3% on the week, but off 4% from its all-time closing high of 12,786.64, set last month. The Standard & Poor's 500 inched up 1.1% to 1402.85, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index gained nearly 1%, to 2387.55.   The short-term prognosis calls for more weakness. The 10-day moving average of the number of stocks hitting new 52-week lows on the NYSE and Nasdaq continues to trend up, says John Roque, senior market technician at Natexis Bleichroeder, while new stock highs move lower. "When new highs are declining and new lows are rising, it's virtually impossible to make money on the long side," he says.   Last Tuesday, Citigroup (ticker: C) unveiled a bid of 1,350 yen per share, or about $11.42 a share, for Japanese broker Nikko Cordial. It might or might not succeed, as some big Nikko holders have balked at the offer, and Nikko might yet be delisted by the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Nevertheless, Nikko would be a good strategic fit for the U.S. bank, says William Smith, president of SAM advisors and an owner of Citi shares.   Smith, who's been critical of Citibank's performance under embattled CEO Charles Prince, and argues that the company should be broken up, says a successful bid at that price would give Nikko to Citibank on the cheap. All the better, he quips, for the time when, as he advocates, Citibank's capital markets division eventually is spun out.   This week, there will be plenty to chew on in the way of earnings reports and outlooks from the big Wall Street brokers.     "Pushing dirt is a great business," says James Hardesty, president of Hardesty Capital Management. Every minute of every day, somewhere in the world "people are moving dirt."   Why, then, is Caterpillar's (CAT) stock down some 20%, to 64.40, from an all-time high of 82 in May 2006, he asks. Good question.   The proximate answer is that Cat missed third-quarter numbers slightly, something the world's biggest maker of earthmoving equipment has rarely done in its history. That spooked investors. Since then, Cat executives have dampened expectations for 2007, saying it will be more challenging than a booming 2006 proved to be.   The hurting housing market -- to which Caterpillar is exposed -- has led many investors to bail out, too. Cat also makes truck engines and parts, and offers financing and insurance for its sales.   Once in a while, however, Mr. Market overreacts, giving long-term investors a chance to buy stocks of big-quality companies on sale. This might be one of them.   Hardesty, who's been buying Caterpillar shares lately, concedes that the homebuilding problems are a headwind for the Peoria, Ill.-based company. But he also notes that Cat's housing exposure is just 8% to 10% of sales, while 50% is outside the U.S., with lots of that in tiger economies like China and India.   China alone "sets the company up for the next two or three years," he believes. Cat sold $800 million of goods to the Middle Kingdom last year, and China should account for 10% of sales, or $5 billion to $6 billion, by 2010, he figures. In 2006, Cat earned $5.17 per share on $41.5 billion in revenue. By 2010 "you're looking at $8-to-$10-per-share earnings," he predicts, noting that implies a $100 stock price. Cat trades at about 12 times consensus estimates of $5.50 per share this year, a pretty reasonable price-to-earnings multiple for a company with few peers.   Speaking of rivals, Hardesty notes that Deere & Co. (DE) shares have done much better than Cat. Granted, Deere isn't a carbon copy, but it is a close cousin. Deere's stock has risen by 22% since May '06, while Caterpillar's has fallen by nearly the same amount.   The caveat, according to Hardesty, is debt. Cat has bumped up debt, with a net debt to capital ratio now at about 50%. That helped improve last year's return on equity to 35%. However, it makes a cyclical company even more exposed to economic downturns. But global growth would have to slow down significantly for that risk to bite. It is more likely Caterpillar's shares will have another life.     Retailers reported February results last week -- up 1.9% at 45 major chain stores, versus 3% in the year-ago month, according to Lazard Capital Markets -- that generally were underwhelming, or in some cases worse.   Gap (GPS) was one of those cases. The the apparel chain has 3,135 stores, a bit less than 1,300 Gap-branded, and the rest mostly Old Navy and Banana Republic. Comparative-store sales, or sales at stores open at least one year, were down 4% last month companywide, and off 5% for the Gap division. To be fair, these declines were better than the even-poorer comps of one year ago, but it is hardly a bright picture. Nor has it been for a while.   For example, the profit projection for this fiscal year is a range of 76 cents to 86 cents, down from 93 cents in the year ended February 3, 2007, which in turn was down from $1.24 a share the previous year.   The company "has lost its groove," noted Carol Levenson, of the bond-analysis firm Gimme Credit, in a recent report. It is afflicted on the one hand by management turmoil; CEO Paul Pressler departed in January, followed by several other high-ranking executives. Gap, which specializes in moderately priced casual apparel,   also has lost market share  to numerous rivals in recent years.   What's perplexing to Levenson and others is that the company continues to add floor space even as it is grappling with contracting sales and gross margins that are at five-year lows. Gap recently announced plans to open 230 new stores this year and close 200, for a net addition of 30 units. The Gap-brand stores, however, will see a net reduction of 50.   But is that enough? Retail-brand momentum is driven by fashion trends, and Gap's glory years appear to be behind it. That doesn't mean it won't make money in the future, but it does mean the company has to adapt, perhaps by quickly and significantly downsizing the number of Gap- brand stores and focusing on its target customer range.   "Any time I see a retailer posting negative comps and struggling on the bottom line, it's a mistake to open new stores," says veteran retail analyst Robert Buchanan of A.G. Edwards.   The company has indeed been slowing growth of net new openings but it has much more to do, argues Buchanan, who has a Sell rating on Gap stock.   Gap needs bold strokes, he says. The solution for the Gap division is to reestablish a more narrow demographic focus from the current wide 18-to-35-year-old cohort to perhaps the 20-to-25-year-old group. And "you don't need the 1,300 Gap stores to appeal to them," but more like 700-800 stores or even less, he says. That's far fewer than Gap's current plan.   "It might be prudent for Gap to figure out what it wants to be when it grows up before opening 230 new stores," Levenson wrote in her report. It's hard to disagree.   The stock, currently 17.84, with a price/earnings ratio of 20, is apt to languish on the shelf like the company's clothes unless forceful action is taken.   Gap responds to critics by noting that "the brand is in the process of focusing on a more specific target customer than the 18-to-35-year-old range of recent years," and that the company has closed more than 400 stores in the past five years. Well, that's a start.     Everybody wants to know what the boss makes, right? This proxy season, investors will get a clearer picture for the first time of what CEOs and other senior execs pull down.   New requirements by the Securities and Exchange Commission for "plain English" pay disclosure in the proxy documents to be sent to shareholders this year include a Summary Compensation Table of the various forms of CEO compensation, which used to be scattered around in various filings. Additionally, there will be a new Compensation Discussion & Analysis section in the proxy.   Both are important, notes Jack Ciesielski, publisher of the Analyst's Accounting Observer. This new information will help shareholders make a more informed decision about whether the CEO is worth his or her salt.   The new requirements pull together in one table all payouts in the form of cash, bonuses, stock and option awards and pension and health-care benefits, among other forms of compensation. "It brings together the one number that everybody is interested in, and that's total compensation," Ciesielski says.   The table isn't perfect, he notes. It lacks completeness when it comes to options grants, because the SEC lets companies break up the value of new grants over the period vested. So, for example, a five-year option grant valued at $10 million will show up as $2 million in the table for this year, even though all of it comes out of shareholder pockets and will affect future earnings. For the total grants amount, the shareholder would have to look elsewhere in the company's documents.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Follow-Up: Will Bookseller's Next Chapter Be An LBO?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   On Monday, March 5, bookseller Barnes & Noble saw its stock drop more than 11%, to 35.56, after the company issued a dour forecast for its current fiscal year.   Among other things, Barnes (ticker: BKS) said it expects to earn $1.65 to $1.80 a share during the fiscal year ending next February. Not only was that significantly lower than the $2.41 projected by the Street, but it also fell short of the $2.20 to $2.30 the book merchant expects to report for its year that ended on Feb. 3 of this year. The primary culprit, management says: its plan to push store traffic higher by increasing product discounts to members of its loyalty program.   We had a sunnier view of the company's prospects last fall ("A Buyout for the Books," Oct. 23), when the stock was around 39. We expected decent earnings growth and thought that the company's relatively debt-free balance sheet and strong cash flow made it a prime buyout candidate.   We still view the shares favorably, as do some big investors.   Pershing Square Capital Management, a New York hedge fund run by William Ackman, tells Barron's that it plans to hold on to its stake -- just under 10% of the outstanding shares. An official of the hedge fund points to several positives.   First, the stock bounced back smartly, trading around 38 at weekend. Likewise, the company's attempts to improve operating efficiencies appear to be taking hold. The company said last week that higher-than-expected profit margins in the fourth quarter had offset somewhat disappointing sales in that soon-to-be reported period. Finally, Barnes & Noble is still a strong generator of operating cash flow, with which it can resume its heavy stock repurchases, when an option-backdating investigation is completed.   Management's poor-mouthing of the coming year, three-quarters in advance of the key holiday selling period, could perhaps betoken something other than just innate conservatism, some investors suspect. Should management want to participate in a leveraged buyout, ultra-conservative forecasts might keep a lid on any potential deal price.   Stifel Nicolaus analyst David Schick recently upgraded the stock from Hold to Buy. In a report, he says that the company's "good real estate and entrepreneurial culture" make it an ideal candidate to go private. Such a deal would likely occur at a price at least 20% above current levels.   Contacted by Barron's, Chairman Leonard Riggio issued a statement saying the company had no intention of going private and that "in the competitive environment in which we exist. . . a strong balance sheet, cash flow and debt capacity all enable the company to ensure a better future."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Rank Group Increases Its SIG Stake, Takeover Offer
Story: ZURICH (AP)--Rank Group Ltd. said Saturday it has increased its stake in Swiss packaging firm SIG Holding AG to 22%, and has upped its offer price to take over the company.   "Rank is now the largest shareholder in SIG, is committed to this strategic position and in due course would anticipate discussing appropriate board representation," the New Zealand-based company said in a statement.   The new offer of 435 Swiss francs a share compares with its earlier bid of 370 francs. SIG recommended last month that shareholders reject the previous offer.   SIG has also received a bid from Elopak AS and CVC Capital Partners. The two companies, operating under the name Romanshorn SA, have offered 400 francs a share.   Rank said Saturday that it purchased 1.43 million shares, but did not say when the transaction occurred.   The move, however, corresponds with an off-bourse sale Thursday of over 1 million shares at 435 francs per share - the same price cited in Rank's new offer, which expires March 29.   SIG shares have soared since the company began receiving acquisition bids last year. Shares fell 4.5% on Friday to close at 444 francs on the Zurich exchange.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 07:22 ET (12:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Follow-Up: Medtronic: Healthier Than It Seems
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Medtronic shares have skipped more than a few beats in recent weeks. The first shock came when January-quarter results showed that the Minneapolis company's U.S. sales of implantable cardioverter defibrillators had slipped 10% from the year-earlier level. Then, an FDA advisory panel recommended against approving a new Medtronic wireless heart monitor, saying it hadn't been shown to reduce emergency medical visits. Medtronic was at $53 when Barron's wrote about the promiseof wireless technologies like the Chronicle-HF heart monitor ("Doctoring by BlackBerry?" Dec. 11, 2006). Friday, Medtronic (ticker: MDT) was trading around $50.   But Medtronic's good prognosis hasn't really changed, and the shares' slump has made its stock more attractive. Medtronic should keep taking defibrillator market share from the Guidant unit of Boston Scientific (BSX), says Lazard Capital analyst Alexander Arrow, while wireless products like the Chronicle monitor still hold promise. "The time to get into these major med-tech bellwethers is when everyone else is shunning them," says Arrow, who's upgraded Medtronic to a Buy, based on the recent 9% selloff. He believes the shares could hit $58 within 12 months.   In the quarter, Medtronic's overall revenue rose 10%, to $3 billion, thanks to stronger sales of devices for spinal surgery, pain relief and clogged heart arteries. Earnings were up 11% to 61 cents a share.   Investors focus on Medtronic's defibrillators because they are its top-sellers, accounting for almost 25% of revenue. In 2005 and 2006, both Medtronic and St. Jude Medical (STJ) grabbed market share at the expense of Guidant, which was jolted by product recalls. Says Lazard's Arrow: "The market share that the Guidant franchise has given up is not going to spring back as quickly as some expect."   But overall demand for defibrillators is growing more slowly in the U.S. than it was when the devices were new and Medtronic was selling the gadgets to patients who'd already suffered heart attacks. Now, Medtronic is seeking growth by selling to patients who get defibrillators to prevent their first cardiac arrest. Because such patients can have no symptoms, they don't always receive a defibrillator implant. Medtronic estimates that defibrillators are in only a third of the 1.3 million Americans who need them; the trick is to develop ways to reach these potential recipients.   Remote monitoring is an important part of Medtronic's growth plan. On March 1, Food and Drug Commission advisers reviewed the Chronicle-HF, which can wirelessly send doctors measurements showing whether a patient's congestive heart failure is reaching danger levels. The company's 274-patient study was designed to test whether patients implanted with the Chronicle device wound up with fewer emergency medical visits. Patients with the device did average 21% fewer emergency visits over six months, compared with an untreated group -- but the results varied so widely within test groups that researchers couldn't show that the difference was statistically significant. Patients in the Chronicle group who were sickest, by one measure, actually did worse than comparable untreated patients.   While praising the technology, the panel voted, 9-to-2, against recommending FDA approval. The agency usually follows its advisers' recommendations.   However, the patients randomly assigned to get a device turned out to have been sicker than those that wound up in the untreated control group. An analysis that accounts for these differences shows the Chronicle implant reducing emergency hospital visits by a statistically significant 40%. But such after-the-fact calculations don't carry much weight in medical research, and the FDA advisers were rightly reluctant to approve the device.   Medtronic hasn't given up on the Chronicle, but the product never represented a big market opportunity by itself, says Stephen N. Oesterle, Medtronic's senior VP for medicine and technology. More significant is an ongoing clinical test of the Chronicle technology in combination with the company's implantable defibrillators. That study will include triple the number of patients enrolled in the failed study, and none will be from the sickest category. The study should take several years.   The company hopes to transform medicine with implanted sensors that allow doctors to remotely monitor and treat patients suffering from heart disease, diabetes or neurological ailments. Medtronic plans to connect a portable glucose monitor it already markets to a wireless handheld communicator -- letting kids with diabetes go to camp while staying in doctors' view.   Lazard analyst Arrow issued a Buy when the drop in Medtronic stock cut its price-earnings multiple to 18.7 times the $2.65 a share he sees the company earning in its January 2008 fiscal year. Historically, Medtronic has traded at 20-to-24-times forward earnings. If its wireless-medicine strategy succeeds, its profits and multiple will become healthier.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Profiting From The Pursuit Of Power
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   Texas Utility TXU's decision last week to scrap plans to build eight -- count'em, eight -- coal-fired plants will wipe more potential energy off the power grid. The move may make the huge buyout of TXU (ticker: TXU) more palatable to environmentalists, but it also means the Lone Star state must find 6,000 more megawatts by 2009 or it may not be able to meet its peak-period needs. There could be occasional shortages and price spikes, all-too-common events for most Americans.   The country's seemingly insatiable need for electricity and its halting progress toward creating more makes the lights shine brighter at Baltimore's Constellation Energy (ticker: CEG), which in the past few years has turned itself into the nation's largest wholesaler of power and supplier to large-scale customers. Moving against popular sentiment into the space left by disgraced merchant Enron, among others, Constellation buys power from utilities and then sells it to customers who operate in deregulated markets and therefore can buy it. It also produces some of the energy it sells.   "We've chosen the free-market model for ourselves," CEO Mayo A. Shattuck III, former head of regional broker Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, tells Barron's. "We're particularly able to leverage our business model during times when power gets constrained. Our knowledge of markets and the physical delivery allows us to provide power at lower cost, relative to our competitors."   Of course, Constellation's stellar positioning and recent string of earnings increases have captured Wall Street's notice. The shares, which Barron's mentioned positively back in mid-2004 ("Juiced Up," June 7, 2004), have more than doubled since then, to about 80 last week. In the interim, a proposed acquisition by Florida's FPL Group pushed the stock up briefly, only to fall when the deal collapsed on regulatory issues. The stock has made up the drop -- and much more -- in recent months.   Some analysts believe the shares have 20% or more upside in coming months. They trade at 18 times 2007 consensus earnings estimates of $4.56 a share (up from $3.88 in 2006), a slight discount to estimated year-over-year profit gains of 19% from this year to 2008.   "We see Constellation as being midway through a tremendous run. It still remains an investment opportunity," says John Bartlett, senior analyst at W.H. Reaves, a New Jersey money manager specializing in utilities, which owns about one million shares.   Shattuck says that Constellation shares, even at lofty levels, are misunderstood. "It's been hard for analysts to break out of their models to come up with an acceptable way to value us," says Shattuck. Partly, that's because the $19-billion-in-revenue power giant hedges so much.   As a result, Constellation has circulated its own sum-of-the-parts valuation (see adjacent table) using widely accepted metrics. It provides its 2007 earnings forecasts for its business units and a range of multiples, based on peer companies'. It then asks analysts to do their own math. Barron's took Constellation up on its offer and asked an analyst to complete the valuation. Using his own multiples for the businesses, the analyst comes up with a net asset value of $90 a share; And, taking the mean of the company-provided multiples, the stock valuation is $110, nearly 40% above recent levels.   Part of the upside analysts and portfolio managers see is right in Constellation's own orbit. The mid-Atlantic area continues to grow in population and commercial outlets but has underinvested in transmission infrastructure.   "The market's only starting to discover the scarcity value of generation capacity, especially in the northeastern United States," says money manager Reaves Bartlett. "Demand is increasing faster in the mid-Atlantic region than in most areas of the country, far outstripping supply," he says.   In late January, Shattuck told Wall Street analysts: "We are just getting started . . . So today's starting point is far better than where we were five years ago. We believe the market environment is very attractive and our team is well-positioned to capture the opportunity." Right now at least, that opportunity seems Texas-sized.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) The Man Who Didn't Come To Dinner -2-
Story: Should Tribune decide to go private, it could copy much of the Zell proposal without dealing with him. More than likely, the Grave Dancer and the Chicago establishment types who are Tribune's directors would have a hard time coexisting on the same board. But he probably would do better for shareholders than the company's directors and managers have in recent years.   Zell's apparent designs on Tribune highlight how unfazed he is by rising competition in the corporate takeover arena from private-equity firms. "They tend to be far more formulaic in their approach, avoiding situations and companies that are complex and have hair all over them," he asserts. "That, of course, has always been our specialty."   In recent years, Zell has scored some big stock gains in a number of unconventional situations. He has made a ton in two companies he helped usher out of Chapter 11: barge maker American Commercial Lines (ACLI) and waste-to-energy concern Covanta (CT). He also exploited an insider-trading scandal to establish a beachhead in Hanover Compressor (HC), whose fortunes are soaring with the frenzied search for additional natural-gas reserves.   And Zell has plenty of skin left in the real-estate game. He has no plans to liquidate his other two REITs, the apartment giant Equity Residential (EQR) or  factory-produced homes for community-living player Equity Lifestyle Properties (ELS).   A Zell-run private-equity fund, Equity International, has deployed $1 billion into South America, including major stakes in two home builders: NYSE-listed Homex Development (HXM) of Mexico and Gafisa of Brazil, which now trades over the counter under the pink-sheet ticker symbol GFSAY.PK. Gafisa soon hopes to have a Big Board listing.   For Zell there are so many new places to visit, so many deals to be done. Unlike in the early 'Nineties, when too much debt almost cost him his empire, he's loaded with cash thanks, to Blackstone. "How can I retire, when I look so forward to coming to work each day?" he asks. Indeed.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(3/10) Google Nears Goal Of Controlling, Targeting TV Ads
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Kevin J. Delaney and Peter Grant   Google Inc. has established a toehold in pursuing of one its next big ambitions: controlling which television ads viewers see and tailoring them to consumers' interests.   The Mountain View, Calif., company honed the highly profitable Internet model of search advertising -- that is, selling ads targeted directly at consumers based on the terms they enter into Web search engines. Last year, the eight-year-old company racked up more than $10 billion of revenue by brokering online ads for itself and its partners.   Now, Google has begun a test run serving up TV commercials to cable subscribers in Concord, Calif., people familiar with the matter say. The pilot project to bring its approach to cable boxes represents a foray into the $54 billion U.S. market for TV advertising -- much bigger game than Google's online turf.   While the effort is in its early stages, the progress underscores how Google could bring changes to how TV commercials are sold and delivered to viewers. Other Internet companies are also pursuing an entree into TV advertising, and any major Google success could eventually challenge the traditional TV and advertising powers.   In the Concord test, Google has been steering TV commercials to subscribers of cable provider Astound Broadband, a unit of WaveDivision Holdings LLC, since last year, according to four people familiar with the matter. When those consumers watch TV, some of the commercials they see have been sold to advertisers by Google and delivered to the cable company so that they appear in the normal breaks in TV programming as other ads do.   If the system is successful, Google could eventually try to establish itself as a middleman for purchasing TV spots, furthering its stated goal of offering advertisers one-stop-shopping for ads across virtually all media. There is no assurance, though, that Google can repeat its success in online-search advertising -- a field in which it had little serious competition -- in the crowded, highly competitive arena of conventional media.   The previously undisclosed Concord effort, being conducted with a small group of advertisers, is aimed at testing the computer and network infrastructure needed for Google to broker and deliver commercials to cable systems more widely. In the test, advertisers are buying commercial placements through an auction system, people familiar with the matter say. But it is at an early enough stage that the buys are being handled manually by Google salespeople, rather than through a full-fledged automated auction system like the one Google uses to sell ads online, one of the people says.   Google Chief Executive Eric Schmidt in January told analysts the company was experimenting with TV advertising, without offering specifics. But he said the company intends to use its technology to better target TV commercials to users. Rather than every household seeing the same commercial, Google in theory might tap databases with information about the demographics of an individual's neighborhood and examine the content of the program being watched at a given moment to better select which ads to beam through the TV. So, for example, a household in an area with lots of children might be more likely to see commercials for minivans than for sports cars.   While federal privacy law restricts what cable companies can do with "personally identifiable information," the theory is that consumers will be better served seeing ads more relevant to them and will perhaps agree to share information about their habits and interests with Google. Such data eventually might allow Google or others to more specifically tailor ads to individual households -- such as beaming ads for dog foods to viewers who own dogs.   "Advertisers in particular will pay much higher rates for ads that are targeted than ones that are untargeted," Mr. Schmidt noted.   At this stage, the commercials aren't targeted to specific households in Concord, which isn't far from Google's Northern California headquarters, people familiar with the matter say. And the company likely won't on its own tap information about a specific household's buying patterns or other behaviors in order to choose the commercials because of the privacy concerns, one of the people says.   A spokeswoman for WaveDivision couldn't be reached for comment, but an executive with Astound, which has more than 25,000 subscribers, confirmed the test with Google is taking place.   "As we have stated publicly, we think we can add value to TV advertising by making this important medium more relevant for users, measurable and more accountable for existing and new advertisers," a Google spokesman said. "As part of this, we are currently running a small, early phase trial working closely with a small number of partners and advertisers."   Google's interest in TV commercials comes as the cable industry itself is turning to advertising as a promising source of revenue. One reason: Technology developments are starting to make it possible to target ads to specific households, as Google envisions. The Internet and cable players all want to play a role.   Several of the largest cable operators have also had discussions with Google about teaming up to do some form of TV advertising. Google has broached the subject with Comcast Corp., the country's largest cable operator, with more than 23 million subscribers, as part of broader negotiations focusing on whether Google will continue as the search engine on Comcast's broadband portal, Comcast.net. Their current deal expires at the end of this year.   Some cable-industry executives are wary about giving a behemoth like Google too much power over their advertising. But many also recognize that Google will likely be a major force in the business. "We all believe as advertising moves from one-way to two-way, the winners are the Googles of the world and others that can provide truly two-way addressable advertising," said Steve Burke, Comcast's chief operating officer, during a recent earnings call.   Google's attempts to extend its ad brokering to traditional media aren't expected any time soon to contribute significantly to its revenue, 99% of which came from Internet ads last year. Its traditional media-advertising efforts have also been bumpy to date. Google's executives admit to problems with the company's first tests of print-ad sales; they have given the system a major overhaul. Analysts say Google hasn't yet lined up enough radio-ad inventory to make its efforts there significant.   While some advertisers are pushing for an Internet-based system for TV-commercial sales such as Google might provide, a group of them chose to team up with online auctioneer eBay Inc. instead. Even then, the TV networks and some advertisers and media buyers have proven resistant to such efforts to overhaul how TV ads are sold.   Some cable operators make as much as 6% of their revenue by selling mostly local ads in the time slots they get as part of their deals with the cable networks they carry. But cable companies feel they could greatly increase ad revenue by introducing a wide range of interactive features. They see as the holy grail of advertising the ability to target different viewers with different commercials suited to their interests, much as Google imagines. "We're talking about delivering to advertisers things they increasingly like about the Internet," says Glenn Britt, Time Warner Cable Inc.'s chief executive.   Time Warner Cable had "preliminary conversations" with Google but the talks didn't advance because Time Warner executives didn't feel Google had much to add to its advertising effort, according to Mr. Britt. "We have the technological capabilities to do those things," he said. "We don't really need them."   Comcast is separately planning targeted ad-serving tests this year with three vendors that have been working close with cable operators on new forms of advertising, including OpenTV Corp., Visible World and Invidi Technologies, according to people familiar with the matter. But Comcast executives caution that next year would be the earliest the company would launch this type of advertising. "In 2007, it's going to be baby steps," said Charlie Thurston, president of Comcast Spotlight, the operator's advertising arm.   Cable operators have to be careful about what they disclose to advertisers and others on customer viewing habits. Federal law privacy restricts what cable companies can do with "personally identifiable information." And while it's unclear exactly how big advertisers and Madison Avenue might welcome Google and other Internet players butting into the TV ad brokering business, some say they are receptive.   "The concept is a homerun with advertisers," says Tracey Scheppach, a vice president and video innovations director at Starcom USA, a media division of Publicis Groupe. "There is just so much inefficiency and a system that allows us to serve the right ad to the right person is one that will be welcomed with open arms."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Beware The Credit Bubble
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   Interview With Carol Levenson   Credit analyst and co-founder, Gimme Credit     Private-equity funds grab headlines with their enormous leveraged buyouts, but they'd barely merit the back page without the corporate bond market, which buys much of the debt that enables these deals. No one knows this corner of the credit markets better than Carol Levenson, an investment-grade bond analyst who helped found Gimme Credit in 1994. The research shop now boasts nine analysts who post pithy, yet insightful, comments on corporate bonds throughout the day. Lately, of course, there's been much on which to opine. When private-equity shops buy out an investment-grade company, for instance, the subsequent financing typically hurts the company's rating and the price of its outstanding bonds. Here's Levenson's take on today's credit environment, how to approach LBO risks and where one might consider hiding.     Barron's: What do you think of the corporate bond market today?   Levenson: We don't take a view on where we think markets are going. But, certainly, we are right there in the trenches observing company-by-company what is happening. We see that, increasingly, event risk is becoming pronounced. It is almost like we never get to do fundamental research anymore because we are so busy examining each rumor and looking at each company to determine who might be doing what in the way of financial engineering. It is not all LBOs. There are huge debt-financed stock buybacks or spinoffs, or asset sales in which the cash gets handed over to shareholders, instead of being used to reduce debt.     Q: How do the leveraged buyouts of today compare to those of the 1980s?   A: Well, when RJR Nabisco issued bonds to fund its LBO, its bonds were sold with coupons ranging from 13% to 17%. That's what people were getting paid to take the risk of owning RJR Nabisco bonds after they did the LBO. Now you are seeing junk bonds post-LBO in the 7%, 8%, 9%, 10% range. The risk premium has gone way down.     Q: What can investment-grade bondholders do to protect themselves?   A: We have a few ways to attack the problem. Most of these deals begin with rumors. We try and assess each rumor for plausibility. We run it through a smell test. Does it make sense for this company to do an LBO? What was the source of the rumor? Was it some equity analyst saying I think this company is more valuable as a leveraged buyout or is it something from a credible news source that seems to have a lot of details from people familiar with the situation? But even if it doesn't pass our plausibility test, if it shows up in the New York Times DealBook column with a lot of details, we get worried about it.     Q: Why are deals so much bigger today than they were years ago?   A: Well, the pools of capital that are ready to be invested are bigger. Leveraged buyout shops also join up with each other now, and everybody contributes some equity. If you look at something like the buyout of Texas utility TXU [ticker: TXU], the investment bankers are contributing equity, in addition to the traditional private-equity funds. And my impression is that the deals are more highly leveraged than they used to be. They can finance these deals without any trouble by raising funds from the banks, the junk-bond market and the equity contributors. There just seems to be a bottomless pit of cheap financing.     Q: Is there anything that could bring the leveraged-buyout craze to a halt?   A: As long as LBO players feel that they can goose up the rate of return by taking a company private and loading it with leverage -- and they have an exit strategy -- LBOs are going to keep happening. Two things would have to change to stop that. The valuation metrics in the stock market would have to go up to make buyouts even more expensive and the risk premium for debt financing would have to go up.   The capital markets exact a very small penalty for a company going down in credit quality. The difference between the spread on the lowest investment-grade debt and the highest-rated junk debt is not so great. The difference is really small between the higher levels of credit quality, like between AAA- and AA-rated bonds. That's why you will see a company allowing its ratings to decline. DuPont [DD], for example, decided that it is not worth their while to be AA-rated anymore. So they intentionally got themselves downgraded by doing a big stock buyback and increasing their leverage.     Q: So if you are a bond investor, how do you avoid some of this risk?   A: Well, here is where I tend to have a different attitude than most people. There are people who will say that bondholders should get more covenant protection, and I don't think that is a bad thing, all else being equal. But it lulls you into a false sense of security. There are ways to weasel out of covenants     Q: What works better?   A: Investors should be paid a higher risk premium for taking this kind of risk. In other words, bonds should be sold with yields that have a wider spread over Treasuries. Or bondholders should demand the real financial covenants that a bank gets. A bank might require that the company maintain a debt-to-Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow] ratio that can't go above Y, or demand that an Ebitda-to-interest expense has to be X.     Q: Investors aren't demanding protection?   A: No. So given weak covenant protection and the low risk premiums in the market, the best we can do is steer people toward names that we think are relatively safe at the moment and away from names that we think are vulnerable. Now, some of the rules that prohibited a leveraged buyout have been thrown out the window. The size rule is one of them -- $20 billion used to be the size barrier for doing an LBO. I've been saying lately that "$40 billion is the new $20 billion." But in the past two weeks, I've had to change that to "$60 billion is the new $40 billion." I would never have thought I would be sitting down and doing an LBO analysis for Home Depot [HD], which would cost $100 billion with a premium.   There also used to be industry features that would mitigate against a highly leveraged transaction.     Q: Like what?   A: You'd rarely see LBOs of companies that were capital-intensive, had cyclical cash flows, were highly regulated or needed steady access to the capital markets. But there are now more exceptions to these rules. The pending LBO of TXU is a huge example of this. I would defy anyone to say that they thought a partly regulated electric utility would be a top LBO candidate, particularly given its size, the regulation involved, its capital needs and the lack of predictability in some of its businesses.     Q: What bonds would you consider safe havens from LBO risk?   A: Well, in my sectors, which tend to be the capital goods and basic industries, you don't see that many highly levered transactions, mainly because of things I've pointed out. They might not have predictable cash flows or they might need a lot of capital. Having a highly organized workforce could also militate against some of the things that a leveraged buyer might want to do. So aerospace and defense is a relatively safe sector. That's particularly true if the company has a big financing arm, like Boeing [BA}. I like Boeing's fundamentals, and I like it as a non-event-risk candidate.   There are industries that I don't think are good for LBOs, like the chemical industry. Technology used to be another safe haven, but that went out the door a couple of years ago when LBOs of Free-scale Semiconductor and SunGuard Data Systems got done.   In the finance area, our analyst feels that older real-estate investment trust bonds have a relatively good amount of indenture protection, though it's not fool-proof. EOP [Equity Office Properties Trust] bondholders are going to make out all right. They are going to be treated fairly and taken out of their bonds at a fair price. They won't be around during the leveraged buyout. They will be gone.     Q: What bonds should retail investors consider?   A: First, a caveat: Most of our investment recommendations are made for institutional buyers. That probably doesn't make such a big difference in stocks, but does make a big difference in bonds. But we do have some names where there are LBO rumors or event-risk rumors, that we have discounted to the extent where we feel that the bonds are attractive.     Q: Great. Let's hear some.   A: Motorola [MOT] is one of them. It's a Carl Icahn scare [He's been buying shares and wants a seat on Motorola's board to pressure the company to give some of its $11 billion in cash to shareholders], and the company does have lots of cash. But as our analyst has explained, Motorola has already done so much to improve the company, what is there left to do? They still need to spend a lot of capital and the valuation is high. They are already doing stock buybacks, and he feels they can do even more in the way of buybacks without materially harming the credit.     Q: Any other rumored LBO targets that you think are good buying opportunities?   A: Investors might consider the bonds of First Data [FDC], Alltel [AT] and Sara Lee [SLE]. In my sectors we have Deere [DE]. There were LBO rumors about Deere a while back. That was a great chance to buy a very good credit that doesn't usually get cheap. Safeway Stores [SWY] is another name. Periodically, there are leveraged-buyout rumors in the supermarket space, where deals have gotten done.     Q: Is there any unifying idea that made you discount LBOs for these companies?   A: Well, there are a few different things, but mainly it has to do with the stock valuations. When you hear the rumor and the valuation on the stock is already pretty high, it can really bust the economics. We actually run these things through spreadsheets to look for internal rates of return for a going-private transaction.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) European Trader: After A Rally, Carrefour Has Limited Upside
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Arindam Nag   The investment in French supermarket giant Carrefour (ticker: CA) by a consortium including Colony Capital, a U.S. private-equity firm, and French billionaire Bernard Arnault has convinced many investors there is more value to be unlocked from the company.   Carrefour's shares, which ran up on the news, and on leveraged-buyout speculation, now trade for 19 times expected 2007 earnings, a premium to the rest of the food-retailing sector. Tesco (TSCO.U.K.), the sector's best operator, trades for 17 times forward profits.   But much has to fall into place for Carrefour to meet such high expectations. The surest way for the company to boost returns might be the acquisition of one of its smaller, privately-held French rivals, such as Auchan. But that doesn't seem to be on the agenda.   The arrival of Colony, a specialist in real estate, as a Carrefour shareholder has focused investors' intentions on how the retailer might manage its physical assets better. Carrefour has been active in sale-and-leaseback deals. It has also sold underperforming assets in places like Japan and South Korea. But it could have been more aggressive, particularly in France, by selling at least minority interests in its hypermarkets.   Such an asset-light strategy would have the benefit of improving Carrefour's shareholder returns, which stood at 3.4% at the end of 2005 ('06 data are not yet available). It would release more cash to return to shareholders, as well as for investment in Carrefour's price competitiveness in France and expansion internationally.   Add the extra financial leverage Carrefour could take on, whether by current management or through a LBO, and there's the potential to improve return on assets.   On the operating front, there's scope for gains from leverage, too. Carrefour seemed to have turned the corner in rebuilding its competitiveness in food sales in France before its weak fourth quarter, but is struggling in the potentially higher-margin nonfood segment, where Groupe Arnault, a luxury-goods giant, could help.   Still, with Carrefour's shareholder base and senior management in a state of flux, it might be early to bet on extra value being created much beyond what's in the stock now.     French businessman Vincent Bollore deserves much credit for his patient and savvy spotting of rich investment opportunities in Europe. But his approach to his 730 million euro ($959 million) investment in British media firm Aegis (ticker: AGS.U.K.) looks less sound. It's about time Bollore decided to make a full offer for Aegis rather than seeking to influence the U.K. company's strategy on the cheap.   For the third time in less than a year, Bollore has asked for the appointment of two of his nominees to the Aegis board. On its own, that looks fine; the French financier owns 29.1% in the company. But he also owns 30% of Havas (HAV.France), the French group that competes head-to-head with Aegis in key segments of the advertising industry.   In fact, it is in Bollore's interest to make a full-fledged bid for Aegis. Apart from the obvious revenue and cost synergies, Havas has high debt. Buying Aegis would transform the French company's finances, as Aegis has consistently delivered positive free cash flow, before acquisitions.   Given that Aegis has a strong media-buying practice and is big in the digital media space -- where Havas is weak -- there is plenty of industrial logic to Aegis and Havas working closely together. The merger also would make Bollore's ambitions of creating a media empire look more credible.   But Aegis investors would be foolish to acquiesce in Bollore's third attempt to get board representation. That goes against the spirit of sound corporate governance. It's hard to imagine the Aegis board having a meeting discussing strategy without Havas management getting wind of it within minutes.   Aegis isn't in the parlous state of affairs Havas was in when Bollore engineered his boardroom coup at the French company in 2005. Havas was underperforming its peers, and still does, lacking the scale of a Publicis Groupe (PUB) or WPP (WPPGY), without much of an emerging-markets profile. It also has little presence in new media.   Aegis has thrived in the niche areas of media buying and media communications, and has shown stable organic growth. This is reflected in the performance of its shares. The stock trades for 12.7 times forward Ebit [earnings before interest and taxes], a slight discount to Havas' 12.7-times multiple, but higher than WPP's 11.4-times or Publicis' 12.3-times multiples.   It seems clear Aegis would fit well within the Havas group. Combined, they might create a strong competitor to the likes of Publicis, WPP and Omnicom (OMC). But to achieve that, Bollore must make a formal offer to all Aegis shareholders, rather than using backdoor tactics to bring the companies together.   ---   MATTHEW CURTIN and ARINDAM NAG are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which the European Trader is based.   ---                          DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
