Headline: Italy's Banca Popolare Italiana, BPVN Hldrs Approve Merger
Story: LODI, Italy (Dow Jones)--Shareholders of Italian mutual banks Banca Popolare Italiana SCARL (BPI.MI) and Banca Popolare Verona e Novara SCARL (BPVN.MI) Saturday approved the merger to create Italy's third-largest bank by branches, called Banco Popolare SCARL.   Banco Popolare will have some 2,200 branches with over 3 million clients, according to a summary provided by the bank ahead of Popolare Italiana shareholders meeting earlier Saturday.   "Banco Popolare will be a big national bank," Popolare Italiana Chief Executive Divo Gronchi said Saturday.   In October, Popolare Verona announced a friendly takeover bid for Popolare Italiana worth around EUR7 billion, or 12 euros per share. The new entity will mainly focus in the wealthy Veneto and Lombardy regions and in Sicily, where BPI has built one of the largest branch networks.   As part of the agreement between the two banks, Popolare Verona Chief Executive Fabio Innocenzi will head the merged group, while Popolare Italiana's Gronchi will chair the management board. Popolare Italiana and Popolare Verona said their deal will bring pre-tax cost savings of EUR500 million a year from 2010 and that there will be a one-time charge of EUR300 million.   Popolare Italiana's decision to merge was taken after the Bank of Italy suggested that the bank find a partner because its finances remained fragile despite corrective measures undertaken by its new management.   In 2005, Lodi-based Popolare Italiana was hit by a financial scandal that culminated with the resignation of its top management including former CEO Gianpiero Fiorani and hundreds of millions of euros in write-offs.   The new bank, Banco Popolare, will become a leader in the consumer credit and leasing business, because it will control 100% of Bipielle Ducato as well as 48% of Linea SpA and 20% of Delta, two leading consumer credit companies.   -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires, +39 347 3563 463; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 09:16 ET (14:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Grayco Partners Executes Investment Agreement With Camden Property Trust
Story: National Real Estate Firm to Develop Multifamily Projects in Target U.S. Markets       HOUSTON, March 10 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Grayco Partners, a national multifamily real estate development firm specializing in well-designed properties in major U.S. markets, today announced an investment agreement with Camden Property Trust (NYSE: CPT) to identify, acquire and develop multifamily projects.  Initial developments under the Grayco-Camden agreement will include two planned communities in Houston, TX - Braeswood Place (344 units) and The Belle Meade at River Oaks (119 units).        (Photo:  http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20070310/CGSA001 )     Grayco Partners is a newly formed national real estate firm specializing in the investment, development and construction of multifamily communities in growing U.S. metropolitan markets.  Grayco founder and President Jeff Gray has directed the development of over $1.5 billion of new multifamily construction encompassing more than 12,000 units in nearly 50 projects.  The company's leadership team has a proven record of success, with over 75 years of experience collectively in the multifamily development industry.     "Our goal at Grayco is to execute quality long-term investment opportunities in multifamily real estate," said Jeff Gray. "This new development venture with Camden will establish a platform for future value creation."     "We are pleased to announce this new agreement with Grayco Partners," stated Richard Campo, Camden's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.  "This type of investment is one of several initiatives Camden is undertaking to expand our development opportunities and maximize our returns on capital."        About Grayco Partners     Grayco Partners is a national real estate firm specializing in the investment, development, construction and management of expertly designed and enduring multifamily communities in targeted U.S. markets. Grayco's business cornerstones are a superior and lasting product, premium location and sound financial structure. Grayco Partners is headquartered in Houston. For more information please visit http://www.graycopartners.com .        About Camden Property Trust     Camden Property Trust is a real estate company engaged in the ownership, development, acquisition, management and disposition of multifamily apartment communities.  Camden owns interests in and operates 186 properties containing 63,843 apartment homes across the United States.  Upon completion of 11 properties under development, the Company's portfolio will increase to 67,605 apartment homes in 197 properties.  For additional information, please contact Camden's Investor Relations Department at (800) 922-6336 or (713) 354-2787 or visit http://www.camdenliving.com .          Grayco Partners Fact Sheet:      http://www.graycopartners.com/corporateinfo/factsheet.php        Grayco Partners FAQs:      http://www.graycopartners.com/corporateinfo/faqs.php       In addition to historical information, this press release contains forward-looking statements under the federal securities law. These statements are based on current expectations, estimates and projections about the industry and markets in which Camden operates, management's beliefs, and assumptions made by management. Forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve certain risks and uncertainties which are difficult to predict.    SOURCE  Grayco Partners       /CONTACT: Jeannine Boswell of Grayco Partners, +1-713-426-2004 x 209, or jboswell@graycopartners.com , or Media, Tom Corbett of Financial Relations Board, +1-312-640-6757, or tcorbett@frbir.com , or Kim Callahan of Camden Property Trust, +1-713-354-2549      /Web site: http://www.graycopartners.com      /Web site: http://www.camdenliving.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 03:00 ET (08:00 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(3/12) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from Feb. 28 through March 7.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO)   An investor group including OppenheimerFunds and D.E. Shaw Valence Portfolios plans to nominate six board membersMarch 23. Oppenheimer holds a 24.5% stake; D.E. Shaw Valence, 9%.     Manatron (MANA)   Constellation Software offered to buy all Manatron's outstanding shares at $10 each; its $9 offer had been rejected. Constellation holds 278,550 shares (5.45%).     Great Wolf Resorts (WOLF)   Jason Ader reiterated his demand that WOLF maximize value by selling itself. Ader holds 2.4 million shares (7.78%).     National Home Health Care (NHHC)   Lawndale Capital Mgmt. said NHHC's rejection of Premier Health Care's proposal to buy NHHC was a "stark example" of the board's breach of fiduciary duties. Lawndale holds 395,045 shares (7%).     Laureate Education (LAUR)   Laureate's No. 2 institutional shareholder, T. Rowe Price Associates, said the proposed management-led $60.50-a-share price is well below Laureate's long-term value. T. Rowe holds 4.2 million shares (8.1%).     Topps (TOPP)   An investor group including Topps Director Arnaud Ajdler and Crescendo Investments believes a pending merger with Tornante and Madison Dearborn Partners isn't in Topps' best interest. The group holds 2.5 million shares (6.6%).     Trico Marine Services (TRMA)   Top shareholder Kistefos suggested TRMA sell itself and return cash to shareholders via a dividend or stock buyback. Kistefos owns 3 million shares (20.2%).     PDL BioPharma (PDLI)   Third Point urged CEO Mark McDade to cut costs and cease further acquisitions. Third Point holds 8 million shares, and options to buy 600,000 more (7.5%).     Sport-Haley (SPOR)   Investor Daniel Zeff, the largest shareholder, said he intends to nominate a director to the company's board. Zeff owns 415,736 shares (18.2%).     Increases in Holdings     Ceridian (CEN)   Pershing Square Capital Management's stake rose to 20.53 million shares (14.5%). On Feb. 27, Pershing exercised call options to buy 3 million shares at an exercise price of $24.26 each and calls to buy 1 million at $24.44. On Feb. 28, it purchased 808,400 more shares for $32.59 each.     PRA International (PRAI)   ValueAct Capital Management owns 4.6 million shares (19%) after buying 700,000 from Feb. 9 through 28 at $19.95 to $22.97 apiece.     Terremark Worldwide (TWW)   Talpa Beheer increased its stake to 6.25 million shares (13.95%), buying 527,400 from Feb. 21 to March 5 at $7.44-$9 each.     Synovics Pharmaceuticals (SYVC)   Investor NalinKant Amratlal Rathod wants the current board to resign and be replaced by directors he'd designate. He owns about 2.6 million shares (9.2%).     Decreases in Holdings     Genesis Lease (GLS)   Fir Tree liquidated its 8.7% stake, selling 2.7 million shares on March 1 at $23.65 apiece. Subsequently, Fir Tree entered into a swap transaction, under which it has an economic interest in GLS shares but not voting or dispositive power over shares held by the swap counterparty.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) The Man Who Didn't Come To Dinner
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   You'd think that Sam Zell would've gotten an invitation to Steve Schwarzman's 60th birthday bash at Manhattan's cavernous Park Avenue Armory. After all, just days before the Feb. 13 party, Schwarzman's Blackstone Group had bought Zell's Equity Office Properties Trust for $39 billion (including debt), making it the biggest leveraged buyout ever. And just about everybody who was anybody in the media, business, Wall Street or government was there to witness what Fortune magazine dubbed the coronation of the new king of Wall Street.   But Zell wasn't among the chosen, and he doesn't seem to care. "I'm not a New York kind of guy," he says in his gadget-filled office in a nondescript Art Deco building in Chicago's West Loop area.   Indeed, Zell isn't.   While Schwarzman is buttoned-down and formal, Zell dressed for his Barron's interview in his usual attire -- wash pants, a sweatshirt and a baseball cap covering his bald pate. He's irreverent and rides fast motorcycles for relaxation.   In contrast to the black-tie pretension of the Schwarzman guests, invitees to Zell's 65th birthday party last fall wore specially designed T-shirts (which served as admission tickets) and dungarees.   The party was held on industrial land Zell owns south of Chicago, in a structure built for the occasion, walled by piled-up shipping containers and lit to resemble an eerie Mayan temple. Giant chandeliers ingeniously constructed of recycled plastic lunch containers and wine glasses lit the interior. There were no testimonials or speeches, such as those delivered at the Schwarzman affair. Just hard-driving rock music, supplied by, among others, Paul Simon, and then a fireworks display, comparable in immensity and length to Shock and Awe over Baghdad.   Now, just five weeks or so after the deal for Equity Office Properties (ticker: EOP) was disclosed, it's been eclipsed as the biggest buyout ever by the proposed $45 billion private-equity takeover of Texas utility, TXU.   Already, stories are surfacing in the financial press that Blackstone might've gotten the best of Zell by cutting deals to unload less than half of EOP's national portfolio for north of $20 billion, realizing a 20% or so profit on the properties. Zell estimates that the gains are half that percentage.   In a recent report, Green Street Advisors of Newport Beach, Calif., puts the gains on sales of the properties, in Manhattan, Seattle, Los Angeles and Orange County, Portland, San Diego, Denver and San Francisco at about $2.3 billion, or 12% of the total, including fees, that Blackstone paid for EOP.   Yet Zell expresses no seller's remorse. For one thing, why complain when you've made an estimated $900 million-plus, in cash, on a transaction? (Zell won't discuss his personal take.) Especially when your net worth, according to Forbes, was already around $4.5 billion? For another, Zell was able to engineer something of a bidding war for EOP between Blackstone and the Vornado Realty Trust REIT (VNO) that upped the takeout price by $3 billion, or 14%, after several months of fevered offers and counter-offers.   Zell permitted both sides to shop EOP properties and to make conditional sales that would be valid only if the suitor prevailed. That, Zell felt, would give each bidder the confidence to take on more debt to push their offers higher. The final price of $55.50 a share was 85% above the $30 or so that EOP was trading at less than a year before the sale.   So Zell has lots of reasons to not begrudge Blackstone whatever it can make by breaking up EOP's 580-building, 105-million-square-foot portfolio. As a real-estate investment trust, EOP had limitations that don't apply to a private-equity buyer like Blackstone. For example, REITs can't liquidate more than 10% of their assets in a given year, unless they file a plan of full dissolution. If the directors had done that, EOP would've had a year to liquidate itself.   "We worried that a lot can happen in a year, like a terrorist attack, a slowdown in the economy and office market, and the like, that would have left us stuck and put our investors at risk," Zell notes. "Blackstone deserved to make a nice profit, since they paid in cash and took on all the risk."   Still, one wonders whether the deal might represent an important peak in the always-volatile office market. Although Zell's timing hasn't always been perfect, he hasn't acquired the sobriquet of "grave dancer" by buying high and selling low.   In real-estate jargon, sales prices are scored in terms of a "cap rate" -- the income that properties throw off in year one of a deal, as a percentage of the total purchase price. The computation is roughly the equivalent of a bond yield. Yet -- as real-estate types endlessly like to point out -- bondholders are entitled only to the bonds' stipulated interest rates, plus repayment of principle. Building returns, on the other hand, can rise markedly from increases in rents and occupancy. Thus, commercial real estate provides a hedge against inflation, while bonds don't.   The cap rate on Blackstone's initial purchase is estimated at 5.1% by Green Street Advisors, while the private-equity giant's sales of the EOP properties went at an average cap rate around 4%. The first-year yields are comparable to those on government bonds, but on much riskier assets.   Green Street analyst Michael Knott questions whether growth will justify these elevated prices. He's especially concerned since office-building cap rates are now lower than those of apartment buildings, retail malls and industrial facilities. Based on total returns -- rents and price appreciation -- all of those have performed better over the past 25 years than the office sector.   Zell, perhaps diplomatically, maintains that the outlook for office properties should remain strong over the next couple of years. But he concedes: "By 2009, the risks of economic slowdown go up markedly, and we'll have a new president by then and perhaps a new party in the White House." The grave dancer hopes that the president isn't a certain ex-First Lady, about whom he expresses a rather pungent opinion.   Under Zell, Equity Office gave its investors decent returns. From its July 17, 1997, initial public offering as a REIT to the completion of the Blackstone buyout last month, it delivered a cumulative 367.2% total return, compared with 307.2% for the SNL REIT Office Index, a benchmark covering 21 real-estate investment trusts. Yet EOP's comparative advantage has flagged over the past five years, during which it returned 171.8% versus 194.3% for the index.   This can be blamed, in large part, on EOP's $7.2 billion purchase six years ago of Spieker Properties, which had a portfolio concentrated in San Francisco and Silicon Valley. The ensuing tech wreck hollowed out occupancy and decimated rental income in the Spieker buildings. EOP cut its dividend rate by 34% in December 2005. That's a big no-no for REITs, which many investors buy mainly for income.   Many observers contend that Zell had miscalculated the value of being in all major U.S. markets to establish economies of scale. Maybe the REIT could buy toilet paper, light bulbs and insurance more cheaply than its competitors. But the office-building leasing and management game is a profoundly regional business, in which local connections and presence, concentrations of prestigious locations and price matter far more than a national footprint.   "Diversification across markets didn't bring the -- I really hate this word -- the synergism that we expected," he admits.   At least EOP was able to sell some of its holdings in secondary cities and suburbs at good prices before those markets weakened. Zell has claimed in the past that he first became worried about the prospects for the less-than-prime office market following a visit he'd made in 2003 to Bangalore, India, to which a lot of office jobs once done in the U.S. have been outsourced.   The snickers over the Spieker deal, however, seem to strike a raw nerve in Zell, who points out that "we ended up getting $12 billion in the buyout for something we only paid $7.2 billion for. If that's the worst deal I ever did, then I'm a happy camper."   Zell is as busy as ever these days, giving no thought to retirement. He's wired, bounding around his office like a hyperactive kid. His only concession to healthy living is drinking bottled water, rather than taking slugs of Diet Coke.   Zell reportedly has made a late-inning bid for the Tribune Co.'s (TRB) newspaper and television-station empire. The only comments he'll make on this are bland ones -- such as that the newspaper business is just like any other for-profit venture.   But Barron's has learned from a person connected to the ongoing auction that Zell's proposal has bested offers by Los Angeles billionaires Ron Burkle and Eli Broad and another by the Chandler Family, disgruntled owner of 20% of Tribune.   This person says that Zell wants to take the company private in a transaction valued at about $13 billion and become chairman of the surviving entity. He would personally put in as much as $300 million and has commitments from lenders for all the debt required. Zell's plan would hand majority control of the company to an employee stock-option plan, in return for the company's being able to use the rich tax deductions generated by this ESOP to sweeten the share price that Tribune could pay existing shareholders.   The Zell proposal assumes that the revenue declines in Tribune's print business will continue. (Late last week, Tribune said that it will not sell any of its newspapers, other than two in Connecticut that Gannett (GCI) is purchasing.)   Tribune's directors plan to decide by the end of the month whether to accept an outside bid for all of the company or to try to recapitalize it by spinning off its 23 TV stations and issuing more debt to pay shareholders a fat dividend. Among other things, the board would like to buy down the Chandlers' stock interest to eliminate the family's abrasive presence on the board.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Prudential Under Pressure To Deliver Turnaround Plan-FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K.-based Prudential PLC (PUK) will face calls for radical action, including a break-up, if it fails to convince investors with its plans for turning around its life assurance business, the Financial Times reported on Saturday, quoting unnamed shareholders.   According to the FT, some shareholders are concerned that plans to be unveiled Thursday by Chief Executive Mark Tucker won't go far enough.   Prudential, which a year ago rebuffed a GBP17 billion approach from Aviva (AV.LN), is expected to announce plans to unlock GBP9 billion of surplus in its life fund.   This could possibly be accompanied by the appointment of a senior figure to represent shareholders' interests, the FT reported.   The group is also expected to announce aggressive cost cutting targets, possibly accompanied by a big outsourcing deal, the report said.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9375     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 06:41 ET (11:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Tech Trader: Looking A Little Harder At Software Acquisitions
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Larry Ellison's Oracle is not the only software company that's looked to acquisitions for growth. The stock market has been pretty happy with the Redwood, City, Calif., company's purchase of firms like PeopleSoft and, just this month, Hyperion Solutions (Ticker: HYSL). Since Oracle (ORCL) snared PeopleSoft at the end of 2004, its stock had risen from about 13 bucks to nearly 20 last year, before easing back to a recent $16.63.   Some second-tier software firms have chosen to grow through acquisition, too, but the way they account for their deals casts a different light on their subsequent results. Two such firms are Nuance Communications (NUAN) and Open Text (OTEX).   Earnings at both companies have benefitted from the significant balance sheet reserves created over the course of their numerous acquisitions, according to analyses by AssayResearch, an independent stock analysis firm based in Alexandria, Va. Such reserves would tend to exaggerate the profitability of these acquisitions.   Open Text is a Waterloo, Ontario, company selling software for managing databases filled with graphics files and other unwieldy data. Assay isn't alone in questioning the acquisition accounting at Open Text. A tiny paragraph in the company's latest annual report notes that the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has questioned Open Text's financial report for the fiscal year ended June 2005 and the three subsequent quarters. "Certain of the Staff comments remains unresolved," says Open Text's disclosure, "and these pertain primarily to our method of accounting for acquisition related costs."   Burlington, Mass.-based Nuance has cobbled together a collection of businesses involving transcription, including the venerable Dictaphone and the software product, Dragon Naturally Speaking. A large part of what Nuance paid for some businesses is in the form of "earn outs" from the post-acquisition performance of those businesses. These arrangements allow Nuance to shift acquisition expenses off its income statement and on to its balance sheet, where they will forever remain, observes AssayResearch in a February 12 analysis of Nuance. I was not successful in my efforts to reach Open Text and Nuance for comment on Friday.   My kids thought it cool that several blogs picked up on my report last week about the professors who found suspicious changes in the I/B/E/S database of stock recommendations maintained by Thomson (TOC). I didn't think it was so cool that Barron's wasn't one of those blogs, so I called up my blogging colleague Eric Savitz to ask what had happened to the magazine's cross-promotion tactics, not to mention our workers' solidarity. Eric explained that his company laptop was dying. He couldn't even get it to rally with the usual slap upside the screen. And that had prevented him from posting his usual Sunday pep talk on the paper's stories.   I had to go to another publisher's blog to find Thomson's response to my story. The story ("Mysterious Changes in Key Wall Street Data," March 5) concerned an academic study reporting almost 55,000 changes in Thomson's database of stock analyst recommendations for the years 1993 to 2002. Some 19,000 recommendations were added after-the-fact. Overall, these post-hoc changes made Wall Street's stockpicking record look better. Thomson's data are used by money managers, finance researchers and The Wall Street Journal to analyze the analysts. However those changes took place, they leave customers unsure of the reliability of decisions based on the I/B/E/S history. The study was performed by Alexander Ljungqvist, of New York University, Christopher J. Malloy, of London Business School, and Felicia C. Marston, of the University of Virginia.   In his blogged statement, Thomson media relations director Joe Christinat called my approach "sensationalist" and lacking in "investigative insight and balance." As for the professors, Christinat essentially said they were wrong and stupid. "The writers of the report clearly had little experience in dealing with Thomson Financial's system," Christinat wrote, "which is designed for financial professionals."   Thomson offered to guide the professors through the database and help them understand the data, wrote Christinat, but the professors declined this offer.   Christinat's simply wrong about the professors' lacking experience with Thomson's data. The profs have each worked with the stuff for seven or more years, and published their results without previous complaints.   By contrast, the people that Thomson tapped to criticize the professors' study have shown that they haven't read or understood the admittedly-technical 49-page paper. One of Thomson's spokespeople urged me to talk to a professor who understood I/B/E/S and would tell me Ljungqvist et al. were wrong. When I called that professor, he said he hadn't read the study.   Christinat also seems misinformed about Thomson's willingness to help Ljungqvist and his colleagues get to the bottom of I/B/E/S's rewritten history. Before releasing the first version of their study last August, the professors say they spent over eight months trying to get Thomson to talk with them about their findings. Only after the paper received press coverage did Thomson begin to work with the authors, says London Business School's Malloy.   Thomson's input "began with a series of implied legal threats by Thomson against the authors," Malloy told me, "and then progressed to a series of communications between the two parties which ended with many of the authors' questions ultimately unanswered and unresolved."   I asked Christinat about legal threats. "I don't think anyone threatened anyone," said the Thomson spokesperson. "We have not taken legal action."   Another thing Thomson has not done is let its data professionals publicly explain why Ljungqvist and his colleagues are wrong. Instead of putting the professors down as dopes, Thomson should tell financial professionals how to reliably use its data.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Fund Of Information: A Good Time To Be Picky In Emerging Markets
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   For U.S. mutual-fund investors, the emerging markets have been a money machine. Through late last week, the MSCI Emerging Markets Index had a five-year annual return of 23.6% in dollars, trouncing the 5.79% gain for the Standard & Poor's 500.   This year the tables have turned, though opportunity remains. Partly due to a steep selloff Feb. 27 -- sparked by a big drop in Chinese stocks -- the emerging-markets index has fallen 3.3% in 2007, far more than the S&P's 0.78%decline.   Some U.S. investors are heading for the exits. For the week ended Feb. 28, emerging-market equity funds, including ETFs, had a net outflow of nearly $764 million, according to AMG Data Services. In the week ended March 7, the net outflow increased sharply -- to $2.4 billion.   On Feb. 27, the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (ticker: EEM), an exchange-traded fund that provides broad exposure to the sector, had a net outflow of about $370 million, according to Barclays Global Investors. The iShares FTSE/Xinhua China 25 Index saw about $21 million go out the door that day. The outflows have persisted for many of the iShares emerging-market ETFs, including funds focusing on Mexico, Brazil and South Korea.   Several emerging-markets-fund hands say this is an overreaction. "In the long run, capital markets will reflect the underlying global economy," says Borge Endresen, a portfolio manager of the AIM Developing Markets Fund (GTDDX), which is up 0.83% this year and which ranks in the top 5% of its Morningstar peer group. He points out that emerging markets account for nearly half of global gross domestic product but far less than half of global stock-market capitalization.   Endresen wouldn't be surprised by more short-term volatility in emerging markets, but asserts that the "vast majority" of U.S. investors are "wildly underweight" these markets.   Underpinning the bullish case is a belief that countries like Brazil, India and China have undergone major economic restructurings. George Iwanicki, global macro emerging-markets strategist at JPMorgan Asset Management, says that many of these countries have adopted sounder fiscal policies, in part by running budget surpluses, and are replacing dollar-denominated debt with borrowings in local currency, a cushion against exchange-rate shocks. "Growth prospects in emerging markets are very positive relative to the developed world," he says.   The firm still likes Turkey and Brazil, two of the more volatile emerging-market countries, but is more cautious about India, because "valuations have gotten very rich and very dependent on sustained rapid economic growth," Iwanicki says.   Another part of the bull case is that the recent selloff has made emerging-market stocks cheaper. On Feb. 27, following the big one-day decline, these stocks traded at 10.76 times forward earnings, versus just above 15 times for U.S. shares, according to MSCI Barra. Iwanicki asserts that the longtime discount for developing markets is narrowing.   He does have concerns, one being the sector's susceptibility to volatility. Another is the additional issuance of emerging-market company shares, creating potential dilution problems -- although it also illustrates the growing demand for these holdings.   Jim Melcher, a global macro hedge-fund manager who runs Balestra Capital, is more skeptical. He's shorting the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index. And he maintains that the overall market has become too enamored of riskier assets, such as subprime mortgages. He frets about "narrowing credit spreads and a credit bubble."   Still, Diane Hsiung, a senior portfolio manager at Barclays who manages the emerging-markets exchange-traded fund, contends that there's a place for these holdings, partly as a portfolio-diversification tool. "There are many companies in emerging markets that hold very prominent positions in their sectors in terms of market leadership," she says, citing TSMC (TSM), formerly known as Taiwan Semiconductor.   Another way for retail investors to play emerging markets is through closed-end funds, including Templeton Emerging Markets (EMF) and Western Asset Emerging Markets Debt (ESD). Both trade at discounts to their net asset values.   Investors in emerging-market mutual, closed-end or exchange-traded fund should realize the comfortable ride of recent years is not likely to continue. But gains remain to be had.   ---               Scoreboard             Tough Week for Gold Funds     -- U.S. diversified equity funds lost an average 0.28%, versus the broad market's dip of 0.05% for the week ended Thursday, reports Lipper. Headline: Barron's(3/12) Does Father Really Know Best?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Joe Queenan   When my son was 13, he started to get interested in the stock market. He'd heard that if you bought stocks like Intel cheap, you cleaned up. So I decided it was time to set up a brokerage account for Gord and give him a hands-on education. I laid down only one rule: He had to keep the money invested in the market until he turned 21. Quick killings would not be part of the plan.   Before we got started, I offered a brief overview of investing, fusing Peter Lynch's dictum to invest in companies whose businesses you understand with the age-old adage to avoid putting all one's eggs in one basket. He accepted the first bit of advice but ignored the second, buying 10 shares each of Microsoft and AOL Time Warner, six shares of Sony and 20 shares of Apple Computer. I warned that he was probably making a big mistake by investing only in technology companies; he riposted that videogames, personal computers and the Internet were things he understood, unlike cars, pharmaceuticals, energy or apparel. Besides, it was his money. Well, my money in his name.   And so it was that in the portentous year 2000, we opened a $3,000 account consisting entirely of tech stocks. What we've learned since is that a parent-sponsored investment project can easily lose its luster for the child. But there's no telling how fascinating it can become for the parent.   Just weeks after we opened the account, the dot-com bubble imploded. Gord's stocks got massacred, the portfolio at one point sinking below $1,300. With the tact for which fathers are famous, I gently chided him for his disastrously narrow stock-picking approach. I then tried to console him with the thought that he was not alone in this ghastly error. But by this point, he no longer seemed terribly interested in stocks, realizing that if he had simply put the $3,000 in a bank account, he would still have the $3,000 -- plus interest. Cash, although he never actually said this, was not trash. This was Lesson No. 1.   With the portfolio entombed, I began wondering just how long it would take for my son to be made whole. I had read about all those people who had put their money in the stock market just before the 1929 crash and had to wait until Eisenhower got elected before they earned a nickel on their untimely investments.   This has been used to explain why an entire generation of middle-class people grew up fearing to buy stocks. I hoped Gord wouldn't make that mistake. Over the next 20, 30 or 40 years, I figured, stocks could serve him well, even tech stocks.   Slowly, the portfolio began to shake off its rigor mortis and meander north, even without much help from Time Warner (now mercifully out from under the AOL aegis) or Microsoft. Sony bounced back from the abyss. But the Lazarus-like resurrection of the portfolio was due almost entirely to the iPod.   Almost from the moment Apple introduced its staggeringly popular, zeitgeist-altering music player, the portfolio began an inexorable rise. By 2005, the stocks were back above $3,000; by the end of 2006, they were worth $4,350 --  up nearly 50% from the original investment, and three-and-a-half times the value of the portfolio during the tech meltdown. Gord had been made whole. Not surprisingly, my son's interest in investing has now been revived -- at least to a point. At the moment, he appears more interested in the "virtual wealth" he has accumulated by playing the online game World of Warcraft.   Curiously, neither he nor my daughter think well of the iPod. My daughter experienced the classic battery-death problem about two years after purchasing her first iPod; my son's unit died almost immediately. Gord thus finds himself in the position of deriving significant financial benefits from a company whose product he does not use and does not even like. But lots of other people do like iPods and do use them. Anyway, if corporations could only sell shares to people who adored their products, who'd buy tobacco or coal stocks? Lesson No. 2.   Had Gord selected just about any other tech stock than Apple when we launched this experiment, his portfolio would still be far underwater. I suppose this is Lesson No. 3, which, as I explained to my son, leads directly to Lesson No. 4: It is better to be lucky than smart. Which leads to Lesson No. 5: Most people aren't lucky, and those who are rarely stay that way.   Now a sophomore in college, Gord will be 21 this fall, at which point he can do whatever he wants with the portfolio. He can buy other stocks, he can load up on what he already has, he can liquidate the portfolio and buy a used car, he can hold on to it forever.   If he does decide to liquidate, I will immediately open an account with exactly the same stocks and hold it for the rest of my life. Just like the decades-spanning project by photographer Nicholas Nixon, who has been taking a black-and-white picture of the same four sisters every year since 1975, this portfolio provides a wonderful opportunity for study. I can examine in detail the effects of the classic buy-and-hold strategy, while simultaneously dissecting the all-the-eggs-in-one-basket approach.   Of course, this could be done without actually buying the stocks, but this would be no fun -- and could be a financial error in judgment should the portfolio continue its northward arc. Watching these stocks ebb and flow has become my hobby: I can't wait to see how Time Warner reinvents itself, how Sony responds to the success of Nintendo's Wii, and how Microsoft fares in the years ahead as Bill Gates slowly fades from the picture. Mostly, I am curious to see how long Apple can stay on this roll. What happens when somebody invents something kewler than the iPod? What happens if Apple itself stops being kewl?   I guess I'm like the guy who buys a dog for his kids and is the only one who ever takes it for walks. Except I'm not the one who bought the dog: It was Gord's decision to buy AOL Time Warner.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Beware The Credit Bubble -2-
Story: Q: What has surprised me are the LBO deals getting done on cyclical companies. Is everyone just assuming that we are never going to see a recession again?   A: Deals are very sensitive to assumptions about Ebitda growth. And they assume that Ebitda growth has to go in only one direction, up. There are ways that LBO guys can get their money out of a deal before anything bad happens. Private-equity investors can pay themselves a big dividend. So they are not necessarily going to be around if problems arise. And, of course the stockholders aren't going to be around either. The only people who are going to get hurt are the bondholders and probably the employees.     Q: So three or five years down the road, how does this all play out?   A: There are going to be enough big blowups that it will be like any other kind of a bubble. But I don't know what will precipitate it. There are so many things that could.     Q: So you think we're in a bubble?   A: We are in a credit bubble, yes. As I said, I don't make big-picture pronouncements, but that's my view from down here in the trenches anyway.     Q: Can you think of an example where the bonds fell a lot after a leveraged buyout?   A: A good example is Harrah's Entertainment [HET]. In June, it issued $750 million of 6% bonds. When rumors of an LBO emerged last fall, those bonds, overnight, lost maybe 10 cents on the dollar. They trade around 90 cents on the dollar. For an investment-grade bond, that's a very big loss. Remember, these are bonds. They're not stocks where you have upside. There is no upside on a bond. [Investors just hope to clip their coupons and get their money back when the bond matures.]   Harrah's used to boast that having the highest ratings in its industry gave it a competitive advantage. They could easily finance their capital programs at a low cost. Now they are going to be up against competitors that aren't stretched to the limit the way they are.     Q: Sounds as if you do a lot of equity research to determine which bonds are at risk.   A: We do have to put ourselves in the mind of an equity investor. Quite frankly, I suffer through some conference calls just to hear what the company is telling equity investors it plans to do to goose returns. If you are a stock investor, do you like to see a big debt-financed share-buyback? I'm not sure. Mathematically, it improves earnings per share, but does it actually help a stockholder? I don't know. Federated [FD], for example, announced a $4 billion stock-buyback today and got downgraded because of it. What's the stock doing? Nothing.     Thanks so much.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 4 US Firms On Shortlist Of UK Nuclear Site Bidders-Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--NM Rothschild has drawn up a shortlist of bidders for Britain's Magnox nuclear sites that include four U.S. companies but none from the U.K., the Daily Telegraph reported on Saturday.   The sale of the sites and the tendering of the clean-up project is part of the U.K. government's drive to privatize Britain's nuclear industry.   The four U.S. bidders selected for the final round include Jacobs (JEC), Fluor (FLR), CH2M Hill and EnergySolutions.   Buying the 10 Magnox sites, which include Sizewall in Suffolk and Hinkley Point in Somerset, will cost around GBP80 million, the Telegraph reported, citing unnamed analysts.   According to the Telegraph, the successful bidder will receive a dowry of two or three years' work cleaning up those Magnox plants that are being decommissioned.   Only a handful of Magnox sites are still operational and all will be decommissioned in the next few years.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9375     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 06:47 ET (11:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Swisscom May Bid For Italy's Fastweb In Coming Days -Source
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--Swiss telecommunications company Swisscom AG (SCM) may make a takeover bid in coming days for Italy's second-largest telecom operator Fastweb SpA (FWB.MI), a person familiar with the matter told Dow Jones Newswires on Saturday.   Based on Friday's closing share price, Fastweb's market capitalization is EUR3.23 billion.   State-controlled Swisscom is currently going through the accounts in Fastweb's data-room after the board of the Milan-based company agreed to this Friday, the person said.   The possible bid may be announced to investors as early as Sunday or Monday, before the start of stock market trading, the person said.   The potential offer was first reported Saturday by Italian media. According to daily La Repubblica, the deal may be worth in the EUR3.5 billion and EUR4.0 billion range.   La Repubblica reported the bid will be offered to all shareholders.   Fastweb founder and Chairman, Silvio Scaglia, recently stated in an interview with an Italian weekly that he would never accept an offer that didn't have equal conditions for to all other shareholders.   Scaglia in January sold 6.3% of his previous 25% stake in Fastweb for over EUR220 million, or at EUR44.4 a share.       Scaglia also confirmed in February he has agreed a lockup deal, barring him from selling his remaining stake in Fastweb for a year.   Scaglia is the company's biggest shareholder with an 18.7% stake, while 69.7% is freefloat, according to securities regulator Consob's web site.   Rome prosecutors have put Scaglia under investigation for allegedly sending false statements on business dealings, the company said late Tuesday. Fastweb and Scaglia repeatedly denied any wrongdoing.   Fastweb has in the last months been in the spotlight as a possible target by foreign rivals. Vodafone Group PLC (VOD) and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp (NWS) were reportedly fingered as possible bidders, but have always denied it.   In February, Fastweb said it plans to pay a dividend of EUR3.77 per share, unchanged from the previous year, despite a 2006 net loss of EUR123.6 million. The market reacted with skepticism to the decision because the company isn't generating profits yet.   Fastweb, which started operating in 2000, confirmed it expects to see its first net profit in this year.   Since it expanded its network to cover most of Italy, Fastweb has aggressively competed with former telecommunication monopoly Telecom Italia SpA (TI).   Fastweb reached over one million clients at year-end, up 49% from 2005, thanks to new commercial offers and an extended coverage of the Italian territory. It also confirmed it posted a first-time positive cash flow in the fourth quarter of 2006.   At the end of last year, the company had a net debt of EUR1.08 billion, up from EUR469.1 million a year earlier.   The Swiss government's stake in the former monopoly Swisscom fell to 54.8% at the end of 2006, it said in January. The government is obliged by law to hold a majority in Swisscom shares.   Company Web sites: http//:swisscom.com                      http//:www.fastweb.it     -Liam Moloney and Giada Zampano, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 339 4607390; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 07:41 ET (12:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Lear To Close Detroit Plant That Makes Armrests, Headrests
Story: DETROIT (AP)--Auto parts supplier Lear plans to close a Detroit armrest and headrest plant that employs about 300 hourly workers.   A closing date wasn't announced.   Lear says the closing is part of a $300 million restructuring that began in mid-1995.   Southfield-based Lear says the company must close plants to be competitive.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 09:46 ET (14:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
