Headline: Fire At Volgograd Oil Refinery Extinguished - Itar-Tass
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The fire at Volgograd's oil refinery was extinguished at 6:16 p.m. Moscow time (1516 GMT) on Saturday. No casualties were reported, the regional branch of the Emergencies Ministry told Itar-Tass.   "The call about the fire at the Volgograd oil refinery was received by the duty officer at 12:51 p.m. Moscow time today. A crude oil distillation plant was on fire. The area affected by the fire was 500 square metres," the ministry's branch said, according to Itar-Tass.   The fire ranked three on Russia's scale of fires. Nine fire crews, 110 personnel, and a Purga-100 (snowstorm) foam system were used to fight the blaze.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 11:36 ET (16:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) New Kid Moves To Head Of The Class
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   When it comes to stock-picking prowess, staying atop the Wall Street broker pyramid is a tough job, akin to hand-to-hand combat. With bragging rights and lucrative trading commissions at stake, there's no shortage of rivals trying to claw their way to the summit.   That makes it all the more impressive when a discount broker like Charles Schwab, which doesn't use the traditional analyst research model, and a smaller, regional outfit like Morgan Keegan repeat as winnersin our stock-picking rankings, and maintain their general dominance.   As we do every six months, Barron's rates the stock-picking abilities of brokers that issue focus lists, or rosters of their best ideas. We rely on data compiled by Zacks Investment Research, an independent outfit that keeps a running tally of the firms' focus lists over various periods.   In the latest study, ended Dec. 31, Zacks looked at the selections of 13 brokers, most of them well known. Reigning long-term champ Schwab (ticker: SCHW) again showed its expertise, taking the top spot over five years, as it did in the previous two rankings. The San Francisco-based firm also came in a close third in the three-year battle, just one-hundredth of a percentage point out of second place.   The three-year crown was snagged by Morgan Keegan. The brokerage house, a Memphis-based unit of Regions Financial (RF), also came in second in the one-year ranking, after being No. 1 in that category in the preceding ratings.   That brings us to the rookie this year, a small broker, Matrix USA, new to our contest, which managed to grab the checkered flag for the short-term rankings -- both for six months and one year. While we're handing out kudos, special mention must also go to Citigroup Smith Barney, which won no category outright, but provided the most consistently strong performance over both the short and long terms, as well as to Banc of America Securities, which scored well over six months and five years. Many brokers exhibited mixed performances, but Raymond James of St. Petersburg, Fla., earned the dubious distinction of trailing both the S&P 500 and the broker average across all four periods presented.   Regular readers of these tables might notice that the average broker's performance has slipped against the S&P 500. In the previous two contests, the average broker beat the key index in each period. This time around, the market bested the average broker in the short term.   Zacks' rankings are straightforward. For over a decade, the Chicago firm has charted performances of the stock recommendations made by America's major brokerages. Zacks looks at the brokers' best-ideas lists, putting a stock in a theoretical portfolio when it's added to a list and taking it out when a broker removes it. Focus Lists, or model portfolios, as some brokers call them, are typically -- though not always -- put together for individual investors and help generate commissions for the firms. The brokerages push the lists as the best of the best, in most cases skimmed from what the firm considers to be the cream of its universe of top-rated stocks.   Although similar in intent, these lists can differ in significant ways. For example, some are updated at regular intervals, while others are changed ad hoc. Most lists are flexible about the quantity of recommendations, but in some cases, the number is fixed.   Most hold 20 to 30 stocks, but Banc of America has just 10, making it more likely that one stellar or disastrous pick will have a big effect on its performance. Other lists, like Schwab's, contain 100 stocks, so the fate of any individual issue matters less in its overall showing. That also means that the Schwab list should have a tougher time beating the index than do shorter ones. More unusually, the discount broker employs a mainly quantitative system, with relatively little input from analysts.   An important note on methodology: Zacks ranks the brokers on an equal-weighted basis. The S&P 500, however, is weighted according to its components' stock-market values. Consequently, the brokers' results aren't strictly comparable to the S&P's. In the past, this has given an advantage to the brokers, because small-capitalization stocks have vastly outpaced large-caps since 1999. So this time around, to help readers get a better perspective on the brokers' relative performance, we've included in the accompanying tables the returns of the S&P 500 adjusted to an equal-weighted basis. Upshot: The 13 brokers, on average, were unable to beat that benchmark in any of the four periods studied.   James Licato, a senior editor at Zacks, says insurance, drug makers and computer software and services were the most popular industries in the focus portfolios at the end of the fourth quarter. That suggests that the stockpickers were leaning defensively. Additionally, the average market value of the focus-list stocks was $49.2 billion at year-end. The top performers had market caps above that; the laggards, below.   In the five-year race, Charles Schwab's Equity Model Portfolio of 100 names, returned 97%, way out in front of second-place Credit Suisse (CS), which had a 57% gain. Schwab also handily beat both the broker average and the S&P, regardless of how the index is measured. Topping the equal-weighted S&P 500 -- which few lists have done over the long term -- indicates that Schwab's picks haven't just been benefiting from the market's small-cap bias. (Large-caps made a bit of a comeback last year, so small stocks provided less of a boost in the six-month and one-year stretches.)   Schwab's stock recommendations are compiled by applying some 18 measures -- including valuation, sentiment, risks to revenue, and momentum ratings -- to the firm's Buy-rated stocks. Among the most important factors in the Schwab method are free-cash-flow trends and asset utilization. In producing this list, Schwab seeks stocks that are undervalued relative to the potential upside surprises they might present to investors over the next year or two.   As noted, Schwab's quantitative system doesn't take the typical analyst-intensive Wall Street approach to picking stocks. Diversification across sectors is important for the company, whose model portfolio mimics the broad market's sector allocations. In other words, an energy stock taken off the list is replaced with another energy company, and a bank with a bank, etc. That dampens sector risk.   "Because it is a diversified list, we tend not to be at the top or bottom of the short-term ranks," says Greg Forsythe, Schwab's director of equity ratings and the founder of its stock-rating system.   Among the list's most recent additions is Convergys (CVG), a Cincinnati-based provider of customer, human- resources and billing services. It's generating "powerful free cash flow," buying back shares and consistently beating consensus earnings forecasts, says Forsythe. Another new Schwab favorite is UST (UST), which sells smokeless tobacco. It, too, has strong cash flow, and it keeps growing faster than expectations, he adds. Two stocks removed from the Schwab list, both for decelerating earnings growth, are AVX (AVX), the electronics-component maker, and oil-and-gas exploration and production company Devon Energy (DVN).   For the three years ended Dec. 31, Morgan Keegan, returned a robust 84% with its 16-to-20 stock focus list, leaving the second-place finisher here, Citigroup Smith Barney (up 53%), in the dust. Like Schwab in the five-year race, Morgan Keegan also thoroughly beat the S&P 500, regardless of the weighting used.   Elkan Scheidt, chairman of Morgan Keegan's focus-list committee, acknowledges that, with his stocks having a median market cap of $1.4 billion, holding mainly small- and mid-caps has helped. More important, however, is "the research we do here," focused on companies that often get little or no attention from the giant Wall Street brokers. "There continues to be value in regional research in companies that aren't widely covered," he observes.   Over three years, liberal investments in energy, transportation and financial stocks drove the focus list's gains, Scheidt points out. But as good as Morgan Keegan's selections have been, the firm performed poorly in the second half, up less than 3%. Scheidt says that holding energy stocks too long -- they're now off the list -- hurt in the third quarter, and that transports hobbled performance in the fourth.   Lately, Morgan Keegan has added Federal Express (FDX) because it expects operational improvements to boost earnings and economic growth to accelerate in coming quarters. Another addition is an Israeli company, Radvision (RVSN), a leading player in the video-conferencing industry. As an original-equipment manufacturer for Cisco Systems (CSCO), it should benefit from Cisco's new push into video conferencing.   The surprise of the contest is Matrix USA, a New York-based broker with just 30 employees, which took the laurels for both six-month and 2006 returns. The firm's director of research, Ivan Feinseth, says its focus list has a "black-box foundation," a quantitative approach that whittles a 3,000-stock universe to about 200 names. Matrix scores the stocks for economic value-added, or EVA, which it measures by looking at growth in the spread between a company's return on capital and its cost of capital. Important factors considered, among others, are excess free cash flow and excess cash per share. "We're not concerned with earnings-per-share consensus estimates," he says.   From a base of those 200 or so stocks, Matrix then employs a more traditional fundamental approach with analyst research and "legwork," Feinseth adds, to come up with a focus list, which has 16 names right now and typically has 12 to 65. "In this way, we capture both the art and science of stock-picking," he quips. Matrix recently has added Brookfield Asset Management (BAM) and removed Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT).   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Reliance Indus To Merge With Indian Petrochemicals
Story: (Updates with company and analyst comments and background information.)   MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--India's Reliance Industries Ltd. (500325.BY) said its board Saturday approved a merger with associate Indian Petrochemicals Corp. Ltd. (500105.BY) via a share swap, strengthening its presence in the petrochemicals business.   The approval to the merger has come about five years after RIL, through its associates, acquired a 26% stake in the erstwhile state-run IPCL under the then government's privatization program. RIL's associates subsequently increased their stake in IPCL further via market purchases and currently hold a 47.3% stake in IPCL.   Under the terms of the merger, which is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, shareholders in IPCL will get one share in RIL for every five shares they hold in IPCL.   RIL said in a statement the merger provides IPCL shareholders "an opportunity to de-risk their investment by participating in the growth opportunities at RIL."   It said IPCL's business portfolio "predominantly consists of commodity polymers, which makes it prone to earnings volatility and cyclical risk," while diversified RIL has interests in oil and gas, refining and marketing, petrochemicals, retail and development of special economic zones.   "This merger will be earnings accretive for the shareholders of RIL and shall provide shareholders of IPCL an opportunity to participate in RIL's diversified business portfolio," said Mukesh Ambani, chairman at both RIL and IPCL, in a statement.   The merger swap ratio was determined on the basis of a joint valuation report by PricewaterhouseCoopers and Ernst & Young.   Sanjeev Agarwal, a partner at Ernst & Young, said the merger ratio was in line with the recent share price movements of both RIL and IPCL.   On the Bombay Stock Exchange Friday, RIL's shares closed 1.2% lower at INR1,318.50 ($29.85) while shares in IPCL rose 3.4% to INR268.60.   Following the merger, RIL's share capital will increase to INR14.54 billion from INR13.94 billion at present.   RIL said its associate companies, which hold a 47.3% stake in IPCL, will receive RIL shares worth around INR37 billion and constituting 2% of RIL's post-merger share capital in exchange for their stake in IPCL.   "The associates will hold the shares for the benefit of all the shareholders of RIL and could monetize the economic value at an appropriate time in the future. These shares could be offered to financial or strategic investors in domestic or international markets," said RIL in the statement.   S. Tulsian, a member of the National Stock Exchange, said that despite the dilution in RIL's equity due to the merger supply of additional RIL shares in the market will be limited because of such an arrangement.     -By V. Phani Kumar; Dow Jones Newswires; 91 22 2288 4212; djn.in@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 05:28 ET (10:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Barron's Online: Countrywide's Curb Appeal
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   Subprime home buyers may be defaulting on payments, but the house that mortgage lender Countrywide Financial built is made of brick, not straw.   With subprime lenders folding under pressure from bad loans, Countrywide's stock has fallen about 20% from its January 52-week high, significantly underperforming the broader market. Yet less than 10% of Countrywide's total loan volume is in the subprime market.   The benefits of revenue diversification and continued double-digit growth of loan-servicing fees may not be reflected in the stock. And the pure mortgage-origination business -- which can be risky because some loans remain on Countrywide's balance sheet -- fell to about half of Countrywide's pretax '06 earnings from nearly 60% in 2005.   There are other reasons to like these shares. The firm should gain pricing power as the subprime loan market shrinks. Its solid reputation as the largest U.S. independent mortgage lender could spur a takeover. And the shares look pretty cheap.   "Countrywide has transitioned from being a mortgage originator to a bank. That is significant, because their earnings are less volatile," says Mitchel Penn, an analyst at Legg Mason Capital Management, which is the second-largest institutional shareholder. The stock is among the top 10 holdings in Bill Miller's Legg Mason Value Trust.   That transition is happening under the watchful eye of CEO Angelo Mozilo, 68, the son of a Bronx butcher who co-founded the mortgage giant in 1969. Countrywide's meat and potatoes is providing mortgages directly to customers. It also services and trades them, and its thrift institution invests in mortgages.   Less than 10% of Countrywide's loans in the fourth quarter were to customers with questionable credit; the industry average is closer to 20%, according to Frederick Cannon, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods (KBW).   And Countrywide's market share is significant -- a 17% stake of the roughly $2.4 trillion U.S. mortgage business and a 12% piece of the mortgage-servicing business, says Basu Mullick, a money manager at Neuberger Berman, a fan of the stock.   Higher interest rates are negative for mortgage originations but a positive for mortgage-servicing fees since Countrywide retains mortgages longer. And Countrywide's bank hedges risk in other ways.   "They have gained market share through every cycle on servicing and origination, and they have diversified their portfolio significantly since the last downturn," says Mullick. "As the market for subprime loans shrinks, margins in subprime will expand and that will be positive for Countrywide."   About 19% of Countrywide's nonprime loans were more than 30 days delinquent at year's end, up from 15% in 2005, according to a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing. But most of its portfolios are conventional mortgages, where 30-day delinquencies only moved to 2.76%, from 2.6% in 2005.   Countrywide sells much of its subprime portfolio as mortgage-backed securities. That removes risk, and still allows for the collection of processing fees. Thus, Countrywide could gain market share even in a "shakeout year" for subprime lenders, Mullick says.   "People got all antsy when Countrywide reported increasing delinquencies in subprime loans in their latest 10-K, while not putting that in the context of Countrywide's greater mortgage banking operation," KBW's Cannon says. "Countrywide has done a good job participating in subprime while limiting their overall risk."   Merrill Lynch this week added Countrywide to its list of 10 most attractive value stocks. The shares trade at 8.3 times estimated forward earnings, versus 10.7 times for mortgage-lending competitor Washington Mutual (ticker: WM), according to Thomson Financial/Baseline.   Merrill and KBW have investment-banking relationships with Countrywide.   Countrywide's shares look even cheaper at 1.5 times book value; the shares have traded at a high of 5.5 times book value in recent years. "Large financial institutions that want to be No. 1 in the country cannot avoid looking at Countrywide," says Cannon.   Countrywide stock moved in January on speculation that Bank of America could be interested in a takeover bid. But BofA's chairman snuffed out the rumors shortly thereafter, and the stock sold off.   Even without an acquisition, according to Merrill Lynch research, "Countrywide is likely to benefit from a cyclical recovery in the mortgage sector that could begin as early as the second half of '07, leading to better core profitability."   True, what matters most is how long it takes for loan delinquencies to play out, and what the Federal Reserve does with interest rates. Investors are likely to sell mortgage lenders first and ask questions later if the news flow is bad. Plus, it's not exactly a vote of confidence that over the past 30 months, CEO Mozilo has unloaded more than 8.7 million Countrywide shares worth $320 million, according to InsiderScore.com. Mozilo has said he must diversify his portfolio. The stock is up nearly 500% since early 2000. Countrywide didn't return a call seeking comment.   "He started the company from scratch, and the sales are under a program," says Penn at Legg Mason. "I don't think his volume will have any effect on the stock."   For all the huffing and puffing about Countrywide and its markets, this house could stand up just fine.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Current Yield: Treasury Yields Rise As Global Stocks Recover
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Randall W. Forsyth   Relative calm returned to the credit markets last week, resulting in Treasury yields retracing about half their declines that followed the sharp global market selloff the prior week.   Even as subprime lender New Century Financial (ticker: NEW) appeared headed toward bankruptcy, the tumult in that sector seemed to ease in tandem with the uptick in the equity market. Credit derivatives tied to the sector (the ABX-HE triple-B-minus tranches, to be specific) continued therebound first noted in last week's column. It's probably no coincidence that the markets for these risk assets stabilized as the yen reversed part of its recent jump vs. the dollar, which took some of the pressure off positions financed by borrowings of the Japanese currency (the now-notorious yen-carry trade).   Most of the rise in Treasury yields followed Friday's release of employment data that, while spot-on with most of the published estimates, were above the whisper numbers being bandied about on trading desks. Nonfarm payrolls rose by 97,000 workers in February on top of an upwardly revised January increase of 146,000, originally estimated at 111,000.   Those data, along with a 0.1 percentage point downtick in the unemployment rate (which is derived from a separate survey) to 4.5%, vastly lowered the odds being placed in the futures on a near-term rate cut by the Federal Reserve, to 32% from 66% just a day earlier.   In the Treasury market, the yield on the benchmark 10-year note rose to 4.585% from 4.507% a week earlier, but was still below the 4.672% level of two weeks prior, just before the global equity markets hit an airpocket. The yield on the two-year note, which is most closely tied to expectations about Fed policy, rose to 4.657% from 4.546% the previous Friday but stayed below the 4.796% of two weeks earlier.   The jobs report showed the economy "is not bad but not great," says Joseph M. Balestroni, head of the domestic high grade corporate bond group at Federated Investments. But with the Fed unlikely to ease, he deems the 10-year Treasury too richly priced in the 4.50% range.   Amid the turbulence in subprime mortgages, the best value in the investment-grade market can be found in the mortgage-backed securities issued by U.S. agencies such as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he adds. As usual, these MBS failed to participate in the fast and furious flight to quality rally in Treasuries because of expectations of increased refinancing activity as mortgage rates dropped.   Essentially, the Fannies and Freddies didn't budge, widening their spread over Treasury yields as the latter declined. These triple-A securities yield about a percentage point over Treasuries, while single-A corporates provide only a 0.90% cushion. And Fannie and Freddie aren't about to be LBO'd.     There's a fate worse than debt, Hillary.   The junior senator from New York sounded the alarm that the burgeoning holdings of U.S. debt by foreigners increase the nation's "economic vulnerabilities." Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, charged that the Bush administration's policies have caused an "erosion of U.S. economic sovereignty."   In a letter to Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson and Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, Clinton suggested establishing some sort of benchmark for foreign-held U.S. debt that would trigger action by the president. Indeed, she said the recent global market selloff was a "wake-up call" on the problem, Bloomberg News reported.   Placing restrictions on overseas ownership of U.S. government securities, as the senator suggests, would effectively solve the problem of growth in America's foreign debt. But the cure would be vastly worse than the ailment, on the order of a lobotomy for a headache.   The real danger posed by foreign purchases of U.S. debt isn't that it is growing; it's that it may stop because global buyers will have had their fill of our paper.   Indeed, far from imperiling the U.S. economy, this foreign capital is keeping it afloat. The purchases of U.S. government debt that so alarms Clinton may be lowering long-term interest rates by 90 basis points (0.90%), according to estimates in a 2006 National Bureau of Economic Research working paper.   More fundamentally, restrictions on the free flow of international capital could imperil the U.S. economy, just as the Smoot-Hawley tariff of 1930 helped set off the Great Depression by killing international trade.   If this recycling of capital is cut off, interest rates would rise and the dollar would fall in a vicious circle, resulting in a a severe recession. The growth in foreign indebtedness that so worries Clinton would be curtailed, but the economy would be crippled.   So, Hillary, be careful what you wish for if you want America's foreign debt curbed.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(3/10) FDA To Review Uses Of Bile-Duct Stents
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Keith J. Winstein   The Food and Drug Administration has called a meeting with makers of bile-duct stents to discuss their heavy use for unapproved, or "off label" surgical applications.   Officials of some stent makers said they fear the FDA will threaten to slow new approvals of the devices or require more-rigorous testing in advance of approval. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, occurs as the FDA, Medicare, and a congressional committee are also looking into off-label use of drug-coated coronary stents amid concerns about their risks in clotting.   An FDA spokeswoman confirmed a meeting but wouldn't say what was to be discussed. The meeting is expected to include manufacturers Boston Scientific Corp., Johnson & Johnson, Abbott Laboratories, ev3 Inc., C.R. Bard Inc., and Alveolus Inc.   Tiny bile-duct scaffolds, known formally as biliary stents, are supposed to prop open the tubes that carry digestive fluids to the intestines, as opposed to blood-pumping arteries, which are the province of stents approved for vascular uses, including drug-coated coronary stents used near the heart.   But since biliary stents are available in much larger sizes than their vascular cousins, doctors commonly use them to prop open large arteries, such as those leading to the legs and kidneys. "Our go-to stent for disease in the legs are biliary stents," said Dr. Gary L. Schaer, the director of the cardiac-catheterization laboratory at Rush Hospital in Chicago. A September 2006 article by an FDA scientist also concluded that "virtually all" kidney-artery operations used stents not approved for that purpose.   Some industry sources estimate that as much as 90% of biliary stents are sold to catheterization laboratories and used off-label in arteries. On-label sales of biliary stents amounted to about $38 million last year, according to Millennium Research Group. Those numbers don't include off-label use in arteries.   Eric K. Mangiardi, the chief executive of Alveolus, Charlotte, N.C., said he was concerned that the FDA would require his company to do clinical trials before its new biliary stent could be approved. He said he hoped for "definitive guidelines around this space. . . . The stents that we're making," he stressed, "cannot be used in the vasculature."   Since biliary stents are largely intended for patients dying of cancer and aren't tested in arteries, the FDA requires far less rigorous study before approving a new biliary stent than one intended for vascular use. A 2003 article by an FDA scientist questioned whether the "booming" biliary stent market was a result of rising needs in cancer patients or represented manufacturers' response to high off-label demand.   In 2004, the FDA forced J&J's Cordis unit to recall an instruction sheet, which wasn't approved by the FDA, for its Precise biliary stent after nine off-label patients were injured.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Enel Says Endesa Stake Buy A 'Unique Opportunity' -SEC Filing
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--Enel SpA (EN), Italy's former power monopoly, said its recent buy of almost 10% of rival Endesa SA (ELE) is a "unique opportunity" to boost its presence in the Spanish markets as well as other European ones, according to a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.   The "investment is consistent with Enel's ongoing strategy to seek new investment opportunities in core energy businesses in Spain, where demand for electricity is expected to grow at a higher rate than the European average, and other European countries and Latin America," said the Italian utility in its filing.   Enel in a surprise move announced on Feb. 27 it bought a 9.99% stake in Endesa, Spain's biggest power company by market value, for EUR4.13 billion. In the following days it said it holds options to buy a further 12% holding of Endesa.   Enel has asked Spanish regulators to allow it to increase its stake to over 10%.   In the SEC filing Enel says it expects a response within the next two months.   The Italian utility said it will seek to gain representation on Endesa's board. Enel said it will be entitled to elect one board member with a 9.99% stake, while that becomes two director with a 15.4% holding, and in the event of a 23.1% stake, then it will be three board directors.   The Rome-based company has said recently it may increase its Endesa stake up to 24.99% -the threshold after which it must make a bid for the rest of the company under Spanish rules.   Enel added that if current Spanish proposals to hike the threshold that triggers an automatic tender is increased to 30% are approved, then it might acquire additional shares to within that limit.     -By Liam Moloney, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 678 2543; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 12:05 ET (17:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Fire Breaks Out At Volgograd Oil Refinery -Itar-Tass
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--An oil refinery is ablaze in Volgograd, a Russian Emergencies Ministry official told Itar-Tass.   The fire broke out in the refinery of Lukoil at about 1:00 p.m. Moscow time Saturday, Itar-Tass reported.   There was fuel discharge caused by depressurization of a vacuum oil refining system, and the fuel burst into flame, the person told Itar-Tass.   About 500 square meters were reported to be ablaze.   The flame may spread to nearby petrol tanks, the person told Itar-Tass.   Nineteen teams of firemen were reported to be working at the site.   There were no reports about victims.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 07:54 ET (12:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Analog Devices   -- ADI-NNM     Moderate Outperform   -- Price 35.10 on March 6   by First Global     ADI bucked declining revenue trend [of] peers [for] marginally better Q1 fiscal-'07 performance. Revenues came in at $657 million, in line with guidance . . . [digital-signal-processing] wireless chipset revenues grew sequentially after decline in Q4:FY06, when inventory corrections at ADI customers negatively impacted sales . . . ADI now trades at 23.3 times our FY07 estimated earnings and 20.1 times our FY08 numbers. Considering relatively better performance [versus] peers, book-to-bill ratio greater than one, and stabilizing inventory, upgrading ADI to Moderate Outperform.     Boyd Gaming   -- BYD-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 44.35 on March 6   by Morgan Joseph     BYD is only operator that can give investors public-equity market exposure to these attractive gaming markets: Las Vegas locals, Atlantic City, N.J., Broward County, Fla. Recent market softness has provided good entry point; shares reached [intra-day] recent high of 49.73 on Feb. 20, [on] BYD's better-than-expected 4Q06 results, and have since declined 11% . . . to 44.35, implying appreciation potential of 26%, to 56 target . . . derived using blended enterprise value/earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization multiple of 9.4 times '08 Ebitda estimates [plus value for growth projects].     Canadian Pacific Railway   -- CP-NYSE     Overweight   -- Price 53.23 on March 7   by Prudential Equity Group   Initiating with Overweight rating and 63 target, based on our '07 estimated EPS of $3.91, assuming shares trade at 16 times our estimate, toward high end of its one- and three-year forward ranges. We believe the higher-than-average multiple is warranted [due to] CP's renewed operational focus. We believe CP's revenue mix is very attractive, since we estimate that only about 20% of it directly competes against trucking, and it has the second-highest exposure to the holy trinity of freight: agriculture, coal and intermodal.     Cox Radio   -- CXR-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 13.90 on March 6   by Barrington Research     Earnings per share of 22 cents for [4Q] and 88 cents for the year topped our estimates of 20 and 86 cents. . . . Pluses in the quarter included 3.8% revenue gain, reflecting flat local revenues but 12.2% increase in national. . . . Cox's long-term incentive plan sets a five-year schedule of increases in incentive awards. Management noted that for '07, in particular, cost and expense levels would increase . . . due in part to . . . expansion of these benefits. . . . We do not expect revenue gains in '07 to be sufficient to overcome this degree of expense increase and therefore estimate '07 EPS will decline to 75 cents.     Credit Suisse High-Yield Bond Fund   -- DHY-NYSE     Sell   -- Price 4.46 on March 1   by Stifel, Nicolaus & Co.     We believe . . . the fund may reduce its dividend in '07. Therefore, we recommend that investors not wait for [this, nor for] the default rate . . . before reducing their position in high-yield funds . . . We view this fund appropriate for aggressive-risk accounts. We believe [it's] trading at lofty levels, slightly below its 52-week average premium of 3.17%.     Landstar System   -- LSTR-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 42.79 on March 6   by Baird Securities     Recommend purchase of LSTR [non-asset-based truckload provider, managing largest fleet of independent truckload contractors in N. America]. Revenue trends are in line with expectations. Volumes slightly lower year/over/year, impacted by slower economic activity and February weather. Yet . . . pricing environment appears to have stabilized at lower levels. Major [crash] in February likely to hit LSTR's full self-insurance deductible of $5 million in 1Q. Target remains 50, [or] 20 times '08 estimates.     MBIA   -- MBI-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 64.39 on March 7   by Friedman Billings Ramsey     Upgraded to Outperform, as we believe the stock's recent poor performance was result of mortgage-related credit concern. MBI's exposure to residential mortgage-backed securities accounts for only 5.8% of net par outstanding, with below-investment-grade subprime credits amounting to only $29 million of $617 billion of net par insured. While we believe that MBI's mortgage-credit exposure is manageable, wider credit spreads resulting from mortgage-industry troubles should translate into more attractive returns. . . . If mortgage-related credit fears migrate to other sectors, financial-guaranty companies stand to benefit further -- but this isn't baked into current estimates. Maintaining 78 target, implying 12.7 times multiple on our '07 EPS estimate and a 1.5 times multiple on current tangible book value.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: HK Leader CNN Interview Apparently Partly Blacked Out In China
Story: HONG KONG (AP)--Chinese authorities Saturday apparently blacked out parts of a CNN interview with Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang, blocking viewers from seeing him discuss democratic reform in the territory.   In the television program, called Talk Asia, Tsang was shown speaking about his plans to consult the Hong Kong public on how to bring universal suffrage to the territory. He said he was anxious to address the democracy issue if he wins a second term in office later this month.   The show was then abruptly cut to make way for commercials, after which the screen blacked out momentarily.   When the show resumed, Tsang was no longer discussing democratic reform, but speaking about his relationship with Beijing state leaders.   "We are not aware that CNN's Talk Asia was indeed blocked during the Tsang interview," said a CNN spokeswoman in Hong Kong, who preferred not to be named.   "We are looking into the matter," she said, when asked whether CNN experienced any technical difficulties during the broadcast.   The show will be broadcast again as scheduled over the weekend, she added.   Tsang, a career civil servant, is widely expected to win another term on March 25 because he is seen as Beijing's preferred candidate. His opponent, pro-democracy lawmaker Alan Leong, has accused him of reluctance to confront Beijing on democratic reform issues.   Hong Kong people have long debated when and how the city could become fully democratic. The former British colony was promised a wide degree of autonomy when it returned to Chinese rule in 1997. But the Communist leadership has not said when Hong Kong could directly vote for its leader and full legislature.   Tsang was picked by an 800-seat election committee, stacked with Beijing loyalists. In the run-up to the election, he has pledged to tackle political reform by running a public consultation later this year.   Discussing his relationship with China's leaders, Tsang said President Hu Jintao showed great interest in the development of Hong Kong affairs.   "There is enormous warmth, rapport and affection from him for Hong Kong as a whole, particularly for the people of Hong Kong," he said.   But Tsang declined to comment when asked whether he has had any disagreements with Hu.   Mainland China restricts foreign television channels such as CNN and the British Broadcasting Corp.'s BBC World to hotels and apartment buildings where foreigners live. Officials monitor the signals and routinely blacks out broadcasts on sensitive topics.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 03:54 ET (08:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Market Watch: A Sampling Of Advisory Opinion
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   Prepared for a Heavy Landing     Zero Hour   By Atlantic Advisors   1560 N. Orange Ave., Winter Park, Fla. 32789     March 7: She packed my bags last night pre-flight/Zero hour nine a.m.: Words from Rocket Man, from the album Honky Chateau, by Elton John.   What is zero hour? Loosely defined, it's the point at which monetary stimulus no longer has an impact on the real economy . . . the economic numbers of late are awful. From housing to durable goods, awful! It strikes me that the reason the real economy isn't following money growth is that debt service has reached the point that it needs to either: a) get paid off; or b) see rising default rates.   Whether we are there now or later . . . we are heading in that direction. It is why I am taking zero credit risk and why I am "renting" stocks, not owning them. . . . To be unaware is dangerous. My goal, if this unfolds, is to be risk averse and then pounce as others sell.   -- Bennet Sedacca     Why Shares Will Rise     Mergers and Acquisitions   By Heartland Adviser/Russ Kaplan Investments   5002 Dodge St., Omaha, Neb. 68132     March 7: Heartland Adviser has often described the benefits of mergers and acquisitions to the holders of a particular stock. There are also benefits to the stocks market in general. Mergers and acquisitions along with companies buying their own stock benefit the general stock market by subtracting from the number of shares of stock which are available.   This subtraction is going on at very high levels. As Kenneth Fisher said [recently]: "Last year's buybacks and takeovers, less new stock issuance, was $585 billion, or 4.5% of gross national product."   We learn in elementary economics when studying supply and demand that as supply shrinks the price goes up. That is exactly what is happening in the stock market and why we are so optimistic long term.   -- Russ Kaplan     Pay Heed to the Pipeline     Investment Controversies Series/Major Pharmaceuticals   By Cowen &. Co.   2 International Pl., Boston, Mass. 02110     March 6: Despite $49 billion of drugs losing patent protection 2010-'12, the industry should be able to generate a respectable 5% to 7% earnings-per-share growth rate in '06-'12. Growth in '11-'12 may be only 4% to 5%, but EPS declines appear avoidable. . . . We believe investors aren't adequately appreciating the potential of Phase II pipelines. Our analysis suggests Schering-Plough and Merck are best positioned for the 2006-'12 period.   -- Ken Cacciatore, Jeff Goater, Ian Sanderson, Steve Scala, Jean Perreault     Look for Your Specs     MacroMinute   By MacroMavens   145 E. 57th St., New York, N.Y. 10022     March 5: Action in the yen has been impressive, with a 3.3% gain against the dollar [the week before last], the knock-on consequences have been surprisingly limited. At the risk of sounding sadistic, there's been disappointingly little pain.   It's not that minus 4% on the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Standard & Poor's 500 and minus 8% on emerging markets isn't a lot . . . but last May, a yen rally triggered a 5.5% decline in the S&P . . . and 26% decline in emerging-market stocks. Ditto credit markets, which have been remarkably quiet. Yet if the recent appetite to short yen is an indication, the carry trade today is more than triple what it was then.   Nowhere is the quiet more suspicious than the high-yield markets (Australia, New Zealand) that were the storied beneficiaries of yen-sourced liquidity. Everyone from global hedge funds to Japanese depositors took advantage of their 6%+ short rates. As expected, the yen notched some of its largest gains against these currencies . . . Yet these bond markets remained inexplicably unharmed. The two-basis-point [a basis point is a hundredth of percentage point] uptick in the N.Z. two-year barely registers on the chart. And in Australia, the two-year rallied five bps on the week.   Huh? Could it be that levered specs haven't sold diddly, that [the markets' drop] wasn't the unwinding of carry trades at all, but simply frightened anticipation thereof? If so we've once again counted our sanity chickens before they've hatched. . . .   [Or could it be that] gold is simply unwinding its recent outperformance and specs are reducing the net long exposure they had built up in recent weeks? We can only hope. . . . Desperate to sustain their fruitful carry trades, specs may well attempt to keep re-sourcing their funds from yen to gold. If so, we will soon see that reflected in the spec position going from substantially net long to net short. Stay tuned.   -- Stephanie Pomboy     Corporate Europe's Potential     Investment Outlook   By Citigroup Private Bank   33 Canada Sq., London E14 5LB England     March: European equities remain cheap relative to credit . . . trad[ing] at a trailing earnings yield of 6.4% (that is, earnings over the past 12 months divided by the stock price), while triple-B-rated corporate-bond yield is 5.6%, according to Data-stream. Equity yields have been higher than corporate-bond yields for more than four years; the disparity remains the main catalyst for shrinking markets. . . .   In our opinion, it makes sense to issue debt and retire equity. . . . Credit rates are accommodative and spreads are tight . . . The ratio of net debt to earnings before interest taxes, depreciation and amortization for the DJ Stoxx 600 index, excluding financials, is likely to be about 1.1 for 2006, more than 20% below average borrowing levels. . . .   Return on equity is the highest in 30+ years. European companies have not needed to releverage balance sheets to boost bottom lines, because . . . topline growth and profit margins . . . [have] driven stocks higher. However, we expect earnings to slow from here. . . . If mega-caps raise leverage to average levels, they could afford to pay a one-time special dividend that yields 5.8% in 2007.   -- Robert Buckland, Jonathan Stubbs   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:01 ET (05:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Norilsk Nickel Wins Tender For OGK-3 Share Issue-Officials
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--A unit of Russian mining giant OAO Norilsk Nickel will take the lion's share of a $3 billion capital increase for wholesale generation company OAO OGK-3, senior Russian electricity officials said Saturday.   State-run monopoly RAO Unified Energy System of Russia, OGK-3's controlling shareholder, said it had priced the capital increase at RUB4.54 a share (US 17 cents).   As reported, the capital increase took a hybrid form being offered first to existing shareholders as a preemptive rights issue. OGK-3 had announced earlier that shareholders had placed indicative bids for some 21.6% of the 18 billion shares on offer. However, the price bid by Norilsk at a subsequent tender for new strategic investors was above the level of most of the indicative bids. As such, Norilsk will buy all of those shares not covered by the preemptive rights issue at the RUB4.54 price.   The issue will raise RUB81.72 billion, substantially more than the company had expected. The total share issue amounts to 37.9% of the expanded capital base.   A UES spokeswoman said Norilsk already owns direct and indirect stakes that total around 13% of the company. Norilsk's stake would approach almost 50% upon completion of the deal.    -By Geoffrey T. Smith, Dow Jones Newswires; (+7 495) 974  8055; geoffrey.smith@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 05:15 ET (10:15 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Swisscom May Bid For Fastweb In Coming Days -Source
Story: (This updates an item that ran at 1241 GMT with Fastweb saying its board will meet Monday)   ROME (Dow Jones)--Swiss telecommunications company Swisscom AG (SCM) may make a takeover bid in coming days for Italy's second-largest telecom operator Fastweb SpA (FWB.MI), a person familiar with the matter told Dow Jones Newswires on Saturday.   Based on Friday's closing share price of EUR42.02, Fastweb's market capitalization is around EUR3.23 billion.   State-controlled Swisscom is currently going through the accounts in Fastweb's data-room after the board of the Milan-based company agreed to this Friday, the person said.   The possible bid may be announced to investors as early as Sunday or Monday, before the start of stock market trading, the person said.   Fastweb's board will meet on Monday "to discuss potential strategic opportunities," the company said in a statement Saturday. It said it issued the press release following a request from securities regulator Consob.   The potential offer was first reported Saturday by Italian media. According to daily La Repubblica, the deal may be worth in the EUR3.5 billion and EUR4.0 billion range.   La Repubblica reported the bid will be offered to all shareholders.   Fastweb founder and Chairman, Silvio Scaglia, recently stated in an interview with an Italian weekly that he would never accept an offer that didn't have equal conditions for to all other shareholders.   Scaglia in January sold 6.3% of his previous 25% stake in Fastweb for over EUR220 million, or at EUR44.4 a share.       Scaglia also confirmed in February he has agreed a lockup deal, barring him from selling his remaining stake in Fastweb for a year.   Scaglia is the company's biggest shareholder with an 18.7% stake, while 69.7% is freefloat, according to regulator Consob's web site.   Rome prosecutors have put Scaglia under investigation for allegedly sending false statements on business dealings, the company said late Tuesday. Fastweb and Scaglia repeatedly denied any wrongdoing.   Fastweb has in the last months been in the spotlight as a possible target by foreign rivals. Vodafone Group PLC (VOD) and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp (NWS) were reportedly fingered as possible bidders, but have always denied it.   In February, Fastweb said it plans to pay a dividend of EUR3.77 per share, unchanged from the previous year, despite a 2006 net loss of EUR123.6 million. The market reacted with skepticism to the decision because the company isn't generating profits yet.   Fastweb, which started operating in 2000, confirmed it expects to see its first net profit in this year.   Since it expanded its network to cover most of Italy, Fastweb has aggressively competed with former telecommunication monopoly Telecom Italia SpA (TI).   Fastweb reached over one million clients at year-end, up 49% from 2005, thanks to new commercial offers and an extended coverage of the Italian territory. It also confirmed it posted a first-time positive cash flow in the fourth quarter of 2006.   At the end of last year, the company had a net debt of EUR1.08 billion, up from EUR469.1 million a year earlier.   The Swiss government's stake in the former monopoly Swisscom fell to 54.8% at the end of 2006, it said in January. The government is obliged by law to hold a majority in Swisscom shares.     Company Web sites: http//:swisscom.com                      http//:www.fastweb.it     -By Liam Moloney and Giada Zampano, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 339 4607390; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 08:33 ET (13:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) New Kid Moves To Head Of The Class -2-
Story: At Citigroup Smith Barney, managing director Marshall Kaplan says a diverse array of stocks and sectors drove the returns of the 20-to-30 member Priority Equity Recommended List. Among them: Pepsico (PEP), Marriott International (MAR), McDonald's (MCD) and Cisco. Kaplan recently added Hershey (HSY), a turnaround story.   With its small 10-member list, Banc of America Securities lives and dies by a few names, as illustrated by its weak one-year finish but strong third-place showing over six months. Tom McManus, the chief investment strategist there, says that Nike (NKE), Yum Brands! (YUM) and MetLife (MET) all helped in the latter half of 2006. His Fresh Money Focus List returned nearly 54% over five years, helped by energy stocks, among others.   In every race there are losers. Bringing up the rear this year is Raymond James, whose performances were once strong but have deteriorated over the past two contests. The Florida broker's chief investment officer, David Henwood, notes that last year's performance was the worst in its focus list's 16-year history. The focus committee made two major mistakes: concentrating too heavily on energy and technology and holding its major underperformers too long. These problems have been addressed, he adds.   Raymond James more recent woes illustrate the difficulty of staying on top. All brokers go through hot and cold stock-picking streaks, so investors should look for durable, long-term outperformers. Based on our rankings, Schwab and Morgan Keegan appear to be in that group.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Speaking Of Dividends: A Growing Threat
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Corporations increasingly are using more of their profits to buy back stock than to enhance their dividends. That could be worrisome for bond buyers.   Edward B. Marrinan, JPMorgan's managing director and head of investment-grade credit strategy, says that "although the credit-risk spotlight has been hogged in the past 18 months by the record spike in leveraged-buyout activity, share repurchases still have plenty of potential to pose trouble for credit investors." In a March 7 strategy commentary, Marrinan and his colleagues, who have been addressing the surging number of share repurchases for nearly three years, note that Anheuser-Busch's (ticker: BUD) new multi-year 100-million-share buyback program led Moody's to cut the brewer's long-term debt ratings. Moody's said it had made the change (down one notch to A2, its sixth-highest ranking) after the nation's largest brewer moved to "a more aggressive financial policy." Standard & Poor's took similar action. Moody's apparently is concerned about Federated Department Stores' (FD) new $4 billion share repurchase, too, and has downgraded the retailer's long-term senior unsecured debt to Baa2 from Baa1. S&P didn't change its ratings, but it does expect the buyback to impede Federated's attempt to improve its credit ratios.   According to Marrinan, the value of share repurchases has climbed 19.4% annually since 1995 and 32.1% since 2002. Buybacks "now represent 67% of total distributions to shareholders and a whopping 67% of corporate profits." On average, repurchases accounted for 56% of all distributions and 58% of earnings since 1995. "The second average, however, drops to 45% when one discounts the inflated levels experienced in the fallow corporate earnings years of 2000 and 2001." Marrinan says that, in absolute terms, S&P 500 companies repurchased $464 billion worth of shares in 2006, an increase of $94 billion over 2005.   "While many credit investors cringe with every share-repurchase headline, these cash distributions . . . are not necessarily always negative," posits Marrinan, "particularly at a time like the present when the corporate sector is so flush with cash." Notwithstanding his observations about Anheuser-Busch and Federated, Marrinan would argue that there are plenty of instances in which a repurchase could be interpreted as a sign of a well-managed company, whose operations are successful enough to accommodate such a use of cash without damaging its credit.   Yet, even as corporate profits have been steadily rising -- at a compound annual rate of 13.7% since 1995 and an astounding 72% since 2002 --  companies have held to conservative dividend policies. The absolute value of dividends paid grew 10.5% annually since 1995 and 12.9% since 2002. Says Marrinan: The 2006 dividend payout ratio of 29% is the lowest in 12 years and "is also lower than the the average of 47% (34% if we exclude 2001 and 2002 when the ratio was inflated due to low corporate earnings)."   To Marrinan, this frugality may be a sign that the corporate sector is "far less willing than in the past to commit to the ongoing financial responsibilities associated with higher dividend payments; it may also be a statement about management's desire to retain strategic control of balance-sheet flexibility."   However, the analyst warns that "corporations are likely to, and will likely remain under intense pressure to, take on additional leverage and sacrifice credit ratings to finance cash disbursements to their shareholders."     The world's No. 1 retailer, Arkansas-based Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) Thursday boosted its annual dividend 31%, to 88 cents a share from 67 cents, payable in four quarterly 22-cent installments. Thus, investors should reap $3.6 billion in payouts over the next 12 months. Wal-Mart has sweetened its dividend every year since its first -- a nickel a share in March 1974.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Profile: Cruising To Retirement
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Werner Renberg   If millions of us are going to live to be 85 or 100 or even older -- distinct possibilities in these times of rapid advances in medicine -- we're going need to do some fancy footwork in the financial-planning department, right?   Well, no, actually. For many folks, there's a remarkably simple and effective way to invest for the long term: Plunk your money in a "life-cycle" mutual fund. These funds, which first appeared in 1994 and are now offered by some 30 fund complexes, offer exposure to stocks, bonds and cash equivalents -- and they automatically switch to less risky allocations as you get older.   With Americans sprouting ever more gray hairs, life-cycle funds are themselves maturing quite nicely. The category's total net assets -- thanks to  both appreciation and net-cash inflows -- surged from $8 billion in 2000 to $110 billion at the end of 2006, according to the Investment Company Institute. The assets jumped 63% last year alone.   In response to the funds' popularity, employers increasingly are making them available as an option in 401(k), 403 (b) and other retirement plans. Some 44% of plan providers in Deloitte Consulting's 401(k) benchmarking survey for 2005-'06 offered "time-based lifestyle funds," versus 28% the previous year. The funds "are gaining in popularity because they largely take care of themselves," says survey director Leslie V. Smith, adding: "This is the first year they've taken off."   Life-cycle funds promise to grow still bigger, if necessary rules proposed by the Labor Department take effect, as expected. The rules, stemming from the Pension Protection Act of 2006, would allow life-cycle funds to be options in qualified retirement plans; an employee who doesn't actively choose a retirement fund would be placed automatically in an appropriate life-cycle fund. While a number of companies already have made the funds a default option, the rules would allow employers to do so without fearing liabilities for any losses suffered by investors -- and that should encourage other employers to join in.   Generally, the funds have been performing well. Life-cycle funds of several management companies returned 11% or 12% in the 12 months through March 1, helped by foreign stocks. And the older funds are starting to develop solid long-term records: A Fidelity life-cycle fund geared to people retiring in 2020 has returned an annualized 8.28% for 10 years, beating the Standard & Poor's 500 through March 7.   Usually, these investments are funds of funds that hold sibling stock and bond funds -- actively managed or index funds -- as well as money-market funds. Some may hold individual securities. But rather than depending primarily on a manager's stock picking, they are about asset allocation and gradual rebalancing according to a predetermined schedule.   The equity portion, which may start as high as 100% for a fund held by a 25-year-old, declines over time but never disappears entirely. And to reflect rising life expectancy, fund firms have been adjusting equity ratios offered in later years to keep them higher than before, in order to keep portfolios growing longer.   At Fidelity and Vanguard, for instance, the equity portion of the longest-term life-cycle funds used to drop to 20% within five to 10 years after retirement. But Vanguard has raised that "permanent" equity allocation to 30%, and Fidelity, while sticking to a permanent 20%, has extended the "glide path" to that allocation to 10 to 15 years after retirement.   As that suggests, there can be subtle differences among the many life-cycle funds now on the market. If your employer doesn't or won't offer them, look for one whose rebalancing schedule and glide path suits your risk tolerance.   And look for funds with low expenses. The expenses generally range from a 0.2% to 2%, depending on the provider and share class. The different funds have various time horizons, usually at five-year intervals. The longest right now is from T. Rowe Price, geared to people who'll turn 65 in 2055.   Despite the growing diversification of life-cycle funds, including sector funds and exchange-traded funds, they still don't provide the customization of a personal portfolio. Investors with more than $1 million or so may want to take more elaborate steps. But for those who like to keep their long-term investing simple, the funds hold clear appeal.   Certainly, more and more investors are casting an eye to the long term. The average life expectancy for Americans who are 65, the "normal" retirement age at which Social Security benefits have commonly begun, has increased to almost 85 -- implying 20 years of life in retirement -- from about 77 in 1900-1940, says the National Center for Health Statistics. And men and women now 65 have a 25% probability of living beyond 92 and 94, respectively, according to analyses of data from the Society of Actuaries.   Although most forecasters have not yet projected average life expectancy at birth exceeding 100, some say it could rise much further in the not-too-distant future.   In the past, retirees were often encouraged to invest in low-maintenance mutual funds, professionally managed at moderate cost. An investor might have held an equity fund and a bond fund, or perhaps an asset-allocation fund, with fixed portions of stocks, bonds and cash equivalents.   But such fixed allocations sometimes generated insufficient growth in early years, or inadequate income later on. It was up to the investor to periodically rebalance his holdings, and not everyone took that job seriously.   Enter life-cycle funds: Originally called Wells Fargo Investment Advisors, Barclays Global Investors was the first into the field, followed by most other big managers.   Now, it seems, such funds are starting to enjoy some golden years of their own.   ---   WERNER RENBERG is a free-lance financial writer in Chappaqua, N.Y.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
