Headline: Negotiations Continue On Stop & Shop Contract; Vote Scheduled Sun
Story: BOSTON (AP)--Negotiations between Stop & Shop and the union locals representing 43,000 supermarket workers continued Saturday in New England.   If union leaders fail to reach an agreement with the company, rank-and-file members of the five locals will vote Sunday on the company's latest offer.   Balloting is to be conducted in the morning and afternoon at separate locations in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island.   A Stop & Shop spokesman says the company remains committed to reaching an agreement. The sticking points include health-care contributions, pensions and wages.   Members of all five union locals last month authorized leaders to call a strike if necessary. The timing of any walkout is uncertain, and would be decided after tomorrow's voting.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 11:45 ET (16:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Report Concludes Calif Gas Facility Poses Safety Concerns
Story: MALIBU, Calif. (AP)--A study on a natural gas facility proposed off the coast of Malibu finds that it would affect air quality, ocean views and marine life.   Australian-based BHP Billiton LNG International Inc. wants to build a terminal that they say will create a reliable source of low-polluting energy.   The 3,000-page environmental report will play a key role in a series of upcoming hearings on the plant.   The study finds the terminal would be noisy, an eyesore and would create emissions. The report concludes that although many of the impacts can be mitigated, some "would remain significant and unavoidable."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 09:49 ET (14:49 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: PDVSA: Fire At Venezuela Oil Refinery; No Injuries
Story: CARACAS (AP)--A fire broke out early Saturday at Venezuela's 180,000-barrel-a-day Puerto La Cruz oil refinery but has been brought under control. There were no injuries, the state oil company said.   Petroleos de Venezuela SA, or PDVSA, said in a statement the incident would not cause any supply disruptions due to sufficient levels of inventory.   PDVSA said officials are trying to determine the cause of the fire, which broke out in the refinery's alkylation unit.   The Puerto la Cruz refinery exports some of its production, but mainly supplies gasoline and other products for the east of Venezuela. PDVSA said those activities were continuing normally.   PDVSA has suffered repeatedly from accidents and mishaps at its facilities in recent years that has drawn criticism of lax safety procedures from Venezuela's head of health and safety.   There were at least one accident and two fires, including one which killed one person and injured four, last year at the Paraguana refining complex, Venezuela's largest.   The Puerto La Cruz refinery was also shutdown or partially shutdown at least twice in 2005, once for a power failure.   Venezuela is the world's eighth-largest oil exporter and was the fourth-biggest supplier of crude to the U.S. last year.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 13:59 ET (18:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) The Electronic Investor: Online Brokers' Hidden Gems
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Theresa W. Carey   ChoiceTrade, one of the two four-star brokers here (CyberTrader is the other), is a small firm that offers traders three distinct platforms. The one with the most features is BonTrade, which is designed to comply with Regulation NMS, the rule intended to assure more transparent and better market pricing, that started to go into effect last week. This platform boasts a Web-based audit panel demonstrating that an order received best execution.   BonTrade's OptionVision tool lets the user graph actual volatility of an underlying stock against the implied volatility defined by market makers. Time frames are customizable, and the user can include a variety of strike prices. As a result, you can see when options are cheap, or when it might be best to sell. The BonTrade platform is $60 a month; ChoiceTrade clients also can choose a less expensive software platform, or use its Web-based system and pay per-transaction commissions.   CyberTrader, Schwab's software offering for hyperactive traders, relaunched last year with more emphasis on ease of use. The platform still has dynamic streaming charts and other tools, but they can now be accessed from a "floating" menu that lets you move windows and dock them where you want. Chart-building is faster. A welcome new item is the Balance Bar, which customers can put anywhere on the screen for viewing real-time information like a daily P&L and margin balance.   Schwab's Website has added new tools providing nearly real-time reports of gains and losses for those with more than $100,000 in household accounts. (Investors with less get 20-minute-delayed quotes.) But some positions don't show up on a P&L until the day after a trade. Frankly, this reporting tool, though improved, still asks too much of the user.   E*Trade has been busy. After folding BrownCo and HarrisDirect customers into its platform, the acquisitive firm launched futures and global stock trading. Clients looking for advice about their investments can run the Intelligent Investing Optimizer, which makes recommendations based on responses to eight profile questions. Another new tool we like is the Risk Analyzer: It lets you weigh your investment choices' possible risks and rewards against your objectives.   Research and reporting are very well done on all E*Trade platforms.   The broker's active investor software program, E*Trade Pro, now has enhanced charting and new technical studies. The charting application also lets you enter an order by double-clicking on a price. Plans are in the works for technical screening and backtesting. By the end of March, Nasdaq TotalView, which offers detailed price and order information on the exchange's stocks, will be included in the Pro platform.   OptionsHouse is shiny and new (see Electronic Investor, Jan. 15), and doing a lot of things right. The brokerage is built on data from its parent company, market maker Peak6. A new tool as of a couple of weeks ago is the Risk Viewer, which has three tabs (P&L, Greeks and Market Exposure) that show portfolio risk by industry, by expiration or by symbol. The firm added mutual funds just last week. From what we've seen, you can expect a lot of interesting technology from this site.   Scottrade launched its new quote and research section, free to customers, in mid-February. These offerings doubled the amount of research available, including additional news feeds and an ETF center. No matter where you are in the Quotes and Research area, if you hover over a ticker symbol you get a small graph, a real-time quote, and links to trading. Customer service is good. This is a solid brokerage for the cost-conscious, long-term investor. It would jump in our ratings if it added some advanced order types, and more customizable features and tools for trading complex options.   For more active traders, the firm offers ScottradeELITE, its software platform. This is an easy-to-use streaming platform that's not as daunting as others.   Another plus, amid all the annoying changes caused by consolidating brokers, Scottrade says it has no plans to go public or sell out. That alone makes it a good bet for electronic traders.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Designing New Profits
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Here's the synopsis of Synopsys: the company is a clear leader in a strong field, and its stock, thanks in part to the recent drubbing of tech shares, looks ripe for the buying.   Mountain View, Calif.-based Synopsys, which automates the design work for computer chips, has seen its shares (ticker: SNPS) tumble 7% in the past two months, to about 25. That's a reasonable 16 times estimated earnings for the fiscal year ending in October '08 -- only slightly higher than the multiple on the S&P 500 and cheaper than many tech shares. Throw in $4 per share in cash, brisk demand for new chips, and growing profit margins and the stock looks even better. Says Yang Lie of Third Avenue Funds: "This is a very well financed company." Another big investor thinks it's worth at least 25% more than the current stock price.   Synopsys, which celebrated its 20th anniversary last year, counts every big chip company among its customers and has had a hand in such top-selling products as Apple's iPods. It is second only to Cadence Design Systems (CDNS) in electronic design-automation for chips, and it dominates in the design of digital chips. Cadence leads in the design of analog chips.   This isn't the first time Barron's readers have heard of Synopsys. In fact, we have hailed it as "one of the best technology stocks you've never heard of" (see "Secret Weapon," Aug. 11, 2003). The company, which had raised its profile by acquiring Avant!, marking the chip-design industry's biggest acquisition ever, saw its shares jump a split-adjusted 17% in the six months after our story. But Synopsys then produced a series of unpleasant surprises, including lower-than-expected bookings. Operating margins plunged well below 10% from a high of nearly 30%. The stock, in turn, fell almost 60%, to under $15, before stabilizing in the latter part of '04.   Some of the problem was in how the company was accounting for sales. Essentially, it has now changed the way it recognizes sales, emphasizing its strong and growing backlog, points out Needham & Co. analyst Rich Valera. That backlog now stands at more than $2 billion.   "We enter every quarter with over 90% of our revenue in hand," says Aart de Geus, Synopsys' charismatic Dutch-born co-founder and chief executive. "The risk of a miss is almost nil. It allows us now to have a longer planning horizon, because we enter the year with 80%-85% of revenue in hand."   De Geus acknowledges that investors also lit a fire under him to boost returns. In the fall, JW Seligman, which owns 8.5% of Synopsys shares, "read him the riot act," recalls Vishal Saluja, who oversees Seligman's Synopsys position. "This is the earnings power of the company and he was seriously depriving us of value each year it took him to get back to margin," Saluja says.   A clear signal of Synopsys' potential was Cadence Design's commitment to 30% operating margins in '07, sharply higher than Synopsys' margins of about 18%. "You can't turn around and say you're in the same business," notes Saluja.   De Geus knew what he had to do. Back in January '06, he had hired a new chief financial officer, Brian Beattie, from another enterprise software outfit, SupportSoft. Margins were already reviving, and together, they began rolling out new products. At the same time, the industry was going their way: After the 2001 slump, chip industry revenues were now above 2000 levels, and the IT universe suddenly had experienced a boom from video, which required more processing power, more display technology, and massive amounts of storage and bandwidth. All of that has required new chips, even if competition among chip makers has been fierce.   De Geus attributes Cadence's margin premium to its monopoly in analog implementation. Though Synopsys focuses on digital chips, analog remains hugely relevant. Wireless applications, for instance, require plenty of analog chips, and consumer appliances are all going wireless. De Geus says Synopsys now is expanding its analog capability, though he declines to give details. "It's an area we'll look forward to with interest," he says. "Our main objective is to live up to the operating profit margin commitment we made to Wall Street."   Last month, Synopsys beat expectations by a wide margin for its fiscal first quarter ended January. It earned 16 cents a share on revenues of $300 million, up from a penny a share and revenues of $260.2 million a year earlier. For the year ending this October, Synopsys forecast it would earn between $1.23 and $1.31 a share, versus 77 cents a share the previous one. Synopsys is moving to boost operating margins to "the mid- to high-20s in the coming years." To that end, the firm has been outsourcing work to low-cost centers like India, Armenia, and China.   Saluja of Seligman thinks margins can reach the high 20s, meaning "the earnings power of this company is more like $2 a share. With $4 a share in cash, and $2 earnings, you can find a way to get to a $36 stock." Now that's a nice design.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/12) Plugged In: Is Openwave In Play?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Investors have a love-hate relationship with Openwave Systems, an up-and-down maker of software for mobile communications.   They love the quality of its industry-leading technology, such as mobile-access gateways that connect wireline telephones to mobile customers, including Cingular's. And they love its $393.1 million cash hoard. But they are less than happy with management, the board and a slumping stock price. Thus, some of the largest shareholders are not contentjust holding the phone.   Openwave CEO David Peterschmidt is engaged in a testy battle with one of Openwave's biggest shareholders, Harbinger Capital, a $7 billion hedge fund with more than an 11% stake in Openwave (ticker: OPWV). Harbinger, which unsuccessfully tried to get two alternative board members elected in January, has filed a lawsuit accusing the software maker of unfair corporate governance practices. The trial is to begin this week in Delaware state court.   Apparently, Harbinger believes that its prescription -- to replace the CEO or force the company's sale -- eventually will prevail. The investment group padded its position by another 600,000 shares last week. Openwave shares were trading around 8.50 Friday, less than half their 52-week high of 22.95, hit in April. A call to Harbinger wasn't returned.   Harbinger isn't alone. Fidelity Management has about a 14% stake. And Carl Icahn ally Jana Partners of San Francisco also has big holdings. "You have a gem, but it is going to take an effort to get management out of office," says Michael Goldman, chief investment adviser for Abbot Capital Partners in Los Angeles, which has a less-than 1% stake.   Goldman thinks that Openwave of Redwood City, Calif., is worth at least $12-$14 a share as a buyout candidate. His math: two times fiscal year 2008 sales projections of about $400 million divided by 85 million shares (after an announced stock buyback is completed). That equates to about $9.40 a share, plus $4.70 in cash. "To me, it's a cheap stock," Goldman says.   Like many wireless software outfits, Openwave has suffered from tight spending by telephone carriers and handset makers. It's also in the midst of product upgrades, which can hurt licensing revenue. But Goldman and others argue that Openwave hasn't reached its potential in part because management hasn't built upon its relationships with the phone carriers and handset makers.   In addition to its mobile-access gateway products, Openwave sells a well-received digital music product. It also recently introduced software that wowed the mobile industry's biggest trade show, in Spain. It lets wireless operators track Internet searches made via the mobile Web browsers in their customers' phones. Many experts think this is game-changing technology that gives Openwave untapped upside in the early stages of the mobile Internet.   Goldman thinks Openwave might be mulling offers to sell, contending that its board met last week. (There was also buzz that the board was in settlement talks with Harbinger.) He says that Openwave shunned previous overtures from Microsoft (MSFT) and Nokia (NOK) for as much as four times sales, but might be exploring its options. "I heard a lot of rumors [last] week," Goldman says. "I would not be surprised if they did sell, even at this depressed price." Openwave CFO Harold Covert would neither confirm nor deny that the board had met. A spokeswoman called later to say the company had no comment about the board or the trial. Stay on the line.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
